en: In the population of Transylvania there are four distinct nationalities: Saxons in the South, and mixed with them the Wallachs, who are the descendants of the Dacians; Magyars in the West, and Szekelys in the East and North. I am going among the latter, who claim to be descended from Attila and the Huns. This may be so, for when the Magyars conquered the country in the eleventh century they found the Huns settled in it. I read that every known superstition in the world is gathered into the horseshoe of the Carpathians, as if it were the centre of some sort of imaginative whirlpool; if so my stay may be very interesting. (Mem., I must ask the Count all about them.)
es: En la poblaciÃ³n de Transilvania hay cuatro nacionalidades distintas: sajones en el sur, y mezclados con ellos los valacos, que son descendientes de los dacios; magiares en el oeste, y escequelios en el este y el norte. Voy entre estos Ãºltimos, que aseguran ser descendientes de Atila y los hunos. Esto puede ser cierto, puesto que cuando los magiares conquistaron el paÃ­s, en el siglo XI, encontraron a los hunos, que ya se habÃ­an establecido en Ã©l. Leo que todas las supersticiones conocidas en el mundo estÃ¡n reunidas en la herradura de los CÃ¡rpatos, como si fuese el centro de alguna especie de remolino imaginativo; si es asÃ­, mi estancia puede ser muy interesante. (Recordar que debo preguntarle al conde acerca de esas supersticiones).
es_translation: In the population of Transylvania, there are four distinct nationalities: Saxons in the south, and mixed with them the Vlachs, who are descendants of the Dacians; Magyars in the west, and Szeklers in the east and north. I am among the latter, who claim to be descendants of Attila and the Huns. This may be true, since when the Magyars conquered the country in the 11th century, they found the Huns, who had already settled there. I read that all the superstitions known in the world are gathered in the Carpathian horseshoe, as if it were the center of some kind of imaginative vortex; if so, my stay may be very interesting. (Remember to ask the Count about these superstitions).

tr_translation: There are four different nationalities in the population of Transylvania: in the south, the Saxons and the Wallachians, who are mixed with them and descended from the Dacians; in the west, the Hungarians; in the east and north, the SzÃ©kelys. I am going among the last group, who claim to be descended from Attila and the Huns. This claim might be true because when the Hungarians conquered the country in the eleventh century, they found that the Huns had already settled there. I read that all known superstitions in the world seem to gather in the horseshoe formed by the Carpathian Mountains as if it were the center of a fanciful vortex; if so, my visit could be very interesting. (Note: I must ask the Count about all this.)

vi_translation: There are four races living in Transylvania: in the south are the Saxons living mixed with the Wallachians, who originate from the Dacian ethnicity; in the west are the Magyars; and in the east and north are the Szekelys. I will stay with the Szekelys. It is said that they descend from Attila and are the descendants of the Huns. This might be true because in the twelfth century, when the Magyars conquered the land they now inhabit, the Huns had already settled there. It seems that all the superstitions in the world exist in the Carpathians, and they always stir the imagination of the local people. If this is indeed the case, then my stay in this land will surely be very interesting. (I will certainly always bother the count with questions about these superstitious beliefs).

en: 4 May.â€”I found that my landlord had got a letter from the Count, directing him to secure the best place on the coach for me; but on making inquiries as to details he seemed somewhat reticent, and pretended that he could not understand my German. This could not be true, because up to then he had understood it perfectly; at least, he answered my questions exactly as if he did. He and his wife, the old lady who had received me, looked at each other in a frightened sort of way. He mumbled out that the money had been sent in a letter, and that was all he knew. When I asked him if he knew Count Dracula, and could tell me anything of his castle, both he and his wife crossed themselves, and, saying that they knew nothing at all, simply refused to speak further. It was so near the time of starting that I had no time to ask any one else, for it was all very mysterious and not by any means comforting.

es_translation: May 4th. I found out that my innkeeper had received a letter from the count, instructing him to secure the best seat in the coach for me; but when inquiring about the details, he became somewhat reticent and pretended not to understand my German. This could not be true, because until that moment he had understood me perfectly; at least he answered my questions exactly as if he understood them. He and his wife, the elderly woman who had received me, looked at each other with fear. He murmured that the money had been sent to him in a letter, and that was all he knew. When I asked him if he knew Count Dracula and if he could tell me anything about his castle, both he and his wife crossed themselves, and saying that they knew nothing at all, they simply refused to say anything more. It was already so close to the time of departure that I didn't have time to ask anyone else, but everything seemed very mysterious to me and in no way reassuring.

tr_translation: May 4th. - I learned that the hotel owner had received a letter from the Count instructing him to arrange the best seat in the carriage for me; however, when I asked questions about the details, he somehow seemed tight-lipped and acted as if he didn't understand my German. Yet this couldn't be true because until that moment he had perfectly understood my German; at the very least, he was definitely answering my questions as if he understood me. He and his wife, the elderly lady who greeted me, looked at each other with an expression full of fear. The man mumbled that the money was sent within the letter and that this was all he knew. When I asked him if he knew Count Dracula and if he could tell me anything about his castle, both he and his wife crossed themselves and refused to speak further, saying they knew nothing. The departure time was so close that I had no time to ask anyone else, for everything was very mysterious and, in any case, not at all reassuring.

vi_translation: â€¢ May 4 The hotel owner himself also received a letter from the count with a request to reserve the best seat on the carriage for me, but when I asked a few questions, the owner seemed hesitant and used the excuse that he couldn't fully understand the German I spoke; clearly a lie because when I first arrived at the hotel, he understood everything I said. The hotel owner and his wife looked at each other worriedly, then turned to me and stammered that the carriage fare had been sent in advance along with a letter, and they knew nothing more. When I asked about Count Dracula and his castle, both the husband and wife made the sign of the cross and replied that they knew absolutely nothing, then signaled to me that they did not want to talk about it anymore. Since the departure time had arrived, I had no more time to inquire with others. I found the situation very mysterious and unconvincing.

en: I handed to him the sealed letter which Mr. Hawkins had entrusted to me. He opened it and read it gravely; then, with a charming smile, he handed it to me to read. One passage of it, at least, gave me a thrill of pleasure.

en: I had hardly come to this conclusion when I heard the great door below shut, and knew that the Count had returned. He did not come at once into the library, so I went cautiously to my own room and found him making the bed. This was odd, but only confirmed what I had all along thoughtâ€”that there were no servants in the house. When later I saw him through the chink of the hinges of the door laying the table in the dining-room, I was assured of it; for if he does himself all these menial offices, surely it is proof that there is no one else to do them. This gave me a fright, for if there is no one else in the castle, it must have been the Count himself who was the driver of the coach that brought me here. This is a terrible thought; for if so, what does it mean that he could control the wolves, as he did, by only holding up his hand in silence. How was it that all the people at Bistritz and on the coach had some terrible fear for me? What meant the giving of the crucifix, of the garlic, of the wild rose, of the mountain ash? Bless that good, good woman who hung the crucifix round my neck! for it is a comfort and a strength to me whenever I touch it. It is odd that a thing which I have been taught to regard with disfavour and as idolatrous should in a time of loneliness and trouble be of help. Is it that there is something in the essence of the thing itself, or that it is a medium, a tangible help, in conveying memories of sympathy and comfort? Some time, if it may be, I must examine this matter and try to make up my mind about it. In the meantime I must find out all I can about Count Dracula, as it may help me to understand. To-night he may talk of himself, if I turn the conversation that way. I must be very careful, however, not to awake his suspicion.
es: Apenas habÃ­a llegado a esta conclusiÃ³n cuando oÃ­ que la gran puerta de abajo se cerraba, y supe que el conde habÃ­a regresado. No llegÃ³ de inmediato a la biblioteca, por lo que yo cautelosamente regresÃ© a mi cuarto, y lo encontrÃ© arreglÃ¡ndome la cama. Esto era raro, pero sÃ³lo confirmÃ³ lo que yo ya habÃ­a estado sospechando durante bastante tiempo: en la casa no habÃ­a sirvientes. Cuando despuÃ©s lo vi a travÃ©s de la hendidura de los goznes de la puerta arreglando la mesa en el comedor, ya no tuve ninguna duda; pues si Ã©l se encargaba de hacer todos aquellos oficios minÃºsculos, seguramente era la prueba de que no habÃ­a nadie mÃ¡s en el castillo, y el mismo conde debiÃ³ haber sido el cochero que me trajo en la calesa hasta aquÃ­. Esto es un pensamiento terrible; pues si es asÃ­, significa que puede controlar a los lobos, tal como lo hizo, por el solo hecho de levantar la mano en silencio. Â¿Por quÃ© habrÃ¡ sido que toda la gente en Bistritz y en el coche sentÃ­an tanto temor por mÃ­? Â¿QuÃ© significado le daban al crucifijo, al ajo, a la rosa salvaje, al fresno de montaÃ±a? Â¡Bendita sea aquella buena mujer que me colgÃ³ el crucifijo alrededor del cuello! Me da consuelo y fuerza cada vez que lo toco. Es divertido que una cosa a la cual me enseÃ±aron que debÃ­a ver con desagrado y como algo idolÃ¡trico pueda ser de ayuda en tiempo de soledad y problemas. Â¿Es que hay algo en la esencia misma de la cosa, o es que es un medio, una ayuda tangible que evoca el recuerdo de simpatÃ­as y consuelos? Puede ser que alguna vez deba examinar este asunto y tratar de decirme acerca de Ã©l. Mientras tanto debo averiguar todo lo que pueda sobre el conde DrÃ¡cula, pues eso me puede ayudar a comprender. Esta noche lo harÃ© que hable sobre Ã©l mismo, volteando la conversaciÃ³n en esa direcciÃ³n. Sin embargo, debo ser muy cuidadoso para no despertar sus sospechas.
es_translation: I had barely reached this conclusion when I heard the large door downstairs close, and I knew that the count had returned. He did not come to the library immediately, so I cautiously returned to my room and found him making my bed. This was strange, but it only confirmed what I had been suspecting for quite some time: there were no servants in the house. When I later saw him through the hinge crack of the door setting the table in the dining room, I had no doubt left; for if he was taking care of all those small chores, it surely was proof that there was no one else in the castle, and the count himself must have been the coachman who brought me here in the carriage. This is a terrible thought; for if so, it means he can control the wolves, just as he did, by merely raising his hand in silence. Why was it that all the people in Bistritz and on the coach were so afraid for me? What meaning did they give to the crucifix, the garlic, the wild rose, the mountain ash? Bless that good woman who hung the crucifix around my neck! It gives me comfort and strength every time I touch it. It is amusing that something I was taught to view with disdain and as idolatrous could be of help in times of loneliness and trouble. Is there something in the very essence of the thing, or is it a means, a tangible aid that evokes the memory of sympathies and comforts? Perhaps someday I should examine this matter and try to tell myself about it. Meanwhile, I must find out all I can about Count Dracula, for that might help me understand. Tonight I will make him talk about himself, steering the conversation in that direction. However, I must be very careful not to arouse his suspicions.

tr_translation: I had barely come to this decision when I heard the great door below close and realized that the Count had returned. He did not come to the library immediately, so I carefully went to my own room and found him making the bed. This was a strange situation, but it confirmed what I had thought from the beginning, that there were no servants in the house. Later, when I saw him setting the table in the dining room through the crack in the door hinge, I became even more certain; if he was doing all these servant tasks himself, it was proof that there was no one else to do them. This situation frightened me, because if there was no one else in the castle, the driver of the carriage that brought me here must also have been the Count himself. This is a terrifying thought; because if so, what does it mean that he could control the wolves by silently raising his hand? How was it that everyone in BistriÅ£a and in the carriage was afraid for me? What did it mean to be given a cross, garlic, wild rose, and rowan? God bless the good woman who hung the cross around my neck, for every time I touch it, it gives me peace and strength. How strange that something I was taught to approach with disapproval and see as idolatry is helping me in a time of loneliness and trouble. Is there something in the nature of this object, or is it a tangible aid that carries memories of love and peace? If possible, I must investigate this matter and come to a conclusion about it someday. In the meantime, I must learn everything I can about Count Dracula, as it may help me understand what is happening. Tonight, if I steer the conversation that way, he might talk about himself. But I must be very careful not to arouse suspicion.

vi_translation: Lost in thought, I suddenly heard the sound of a door closing downstairs: the old count had returned. He did not go straight to the library. I had to stealthily return to my room. I was very surprised to see him in there making my bed! Despite my immense astonishment, it confirmed something I had suspected since setting foot in this castle: there were no servants in the house. And a moment later, when I looked through the crack in the door and saw him setting the dining table in the dining room, I had no more doubts, for if he was taking on these tasks, it was simply because he had no servants to do them for him. I shuddered in fear at the thought that if there was no one else in the castle, the coachman who brought me here was none other than the old count himself. If that were true, what would it say about the power he wielded by raising his hand to command the wolves? Why were the people at the Bistritz hotel and all my fellow travelers on the first coach so fearful for me? Why did they give me a small cross, a sprig of garlic, and a wild rose? May God bless the kind-hearted woman who gave me the rosary with the cross? For every time I touch that cross, I feel as if I am imbued with strength and courage. I was very surprised to see that the cross, an inanimate object, something I had long considered useless, merely a symbol of faith, could somewhat save me from feelings of loneliness and despair. Does that small cross have an intrinsic power, or is it merely an object that revives old memories? I hope that one day, I will be able to test the matter to provide an answer. In the meantime, I must grasp as much as possible about Count Dracula; perhaps it will help me understand everything that is happening. And perhaps tonight he will reveal many things if I steer the conversation in this direction. However, I must also be very cautious so that he cannot suspect my inner thoughts.

en: He hobbled away, and I could see him hurrying, as well as he could, down the steps. The steps are a great feature on the place. They lead from the town up to the church, there are hundreds of themâ€”I do not know how manyâ€”and they wind up in a delicate curve; the slope is so gentle that a horse could easily walk up and down them. I think they must originally have had something to do with the abbey. I shall go home too. Lucy went out visiting with her mother, and as they were only duty calls, I did not go. They will be home by this.
es: Se alejÃ³ cojeando, y pude ver que se apresuraba, tanto como podÃ­a, gradas abajo. Los graderÃ­os son un rasgo distintivo de este lugar. Conducen del pueblo a la iglesia; hay cientos de ellos (no sÃ© cuantos) y se enroscan en delicadas curvas; el declive es tan leve que un caballo puede fÃ¡cilmente subirlos o bajarlos. Creo que originalmente deben haber tenido algo que ver con la abadÃ­a. Me irÃ© hacia mi casa tambiÃ©n. Lucy saliÃ³ a hacer algunas visitas con su madre, y como sÃ³lo eran visitas de cortesÃ­a, yo no fui. Pero ya es hora de que estÃ©n de regreso.
es_translation: He limped away, and I could see that he was hurrying, as much as he could, down the steps. The bleachers are a distinctive feature of this place. They lead from the village to the church; there are hundreds of them (I don't know how many) and they twist in delicate curves; the slope is so gentle that a horse can easily go up or down them. I think they must have originally had something to do with the abbey. I will head home as well. Lucy went out to make some visits with her mother, and since they were only courtesy visits, I did not go. But it is time for them to be back by now.

tr_translation: He limped away, down the stairs, and I could see him descending as quickly as he could. The stairs are one of the important features of this place. They go from the town to the church; there are hundreds of steps - I don't know how many - and they turn with a gentle curve; the incline is so slight that a horse can easily go up and down. I think they originally had some connection with the Monastery. I should go home too. Lucy had gone to pay visits with her mother, and since these visits were out of duty, I did not go. They must have returned home by now.

vi_translation: The old man dragged his steps home. I kept watching the elderly figure trying to descend the stone steps as quickly as possible, with the limited ability of someone in their twilight years. The stone steps are one of the very distinctive features of this area. They run from the city up to the church; there are easily a few hundred steps, somewhat spiraling. In fact, they are not very precarious, as a horse can easily gallop up and down them. Surely in the past, these steps must have also led to the areas surrounding the monastery... Perhaps I should go home as well. Lucy and her mother have gone sightseeing all afternoon. I don't want to disturb them. By now, they are probably about to return.

en: â€œTo please their relatives, you suppose!â€ This he said with intense scorn. â€œHow will it pleasure their relatives to know that lies is wrote over them, and that everybody in the place knows that they be lies?â€ He pointed to a stone at our feet which had been laid down as a slab, on which the seat was rested, close to the edge of the cliff. â€œRead the lies on that thruff-stean,â€ he said. The letters were upside down to me from where I sat, but Lucy was more opposite to them, so she leant over and read:â€”

vi_translation: The old man mocked, mimicking my question. - Try telling me, what pleasure is there for the families when they know that the inscriptions on those graves are just lies, and that everyone knows it? Then he pointed to a stone lying at our feet, like a slab keeping the bench balanced on the edge of the cliff: â€” Read these lines of lies below. vi_translation: â€¢ 11 AM It didn't take long before the warden hurriedly ran to inform me that Renfield was very sick, that he had vomited a whole pile of bird feathers, just bird feathers. "Doctor," the warden told me, "I believe he has eaten his entire flock of birds alive?"

en: On 17 July, yesterday, one of the men, Olgaren, came to my cabin, and in an awestruck way confided to me that he thought there was a strange man aboard the ship. He said that in his watch he had been sheltering behind the deck-house, as there was a rain-storm, when he saw a tall, thin man, who was not like any of the crew, come up the companion-way, and go along the deck forward, and disappear. He followed cautiously, but when he got to bows found no one, and the hatchways were all closed. He was in a panic of superstitious fear, and I am afraid the panic may spread. To allay it, I shall to-day search entire ship carefully from stem to stern.
es: El 17 de julio, ayer, uno de los hombres, Olgaren, llegÃ³ a mi cabina y de una manera confidencial y temerosa me dijo que Ã©l pensaba que habÃ­a un hombre extraÃ±o a bordo del barco. Me narrÃ³ que en su guardia habÃ­a estado escondido detrÃ¡s de la cÃ¡mara de cubierta, pues habÃ­a lluvia de tormenta, cuando vio a un hombre alto, delgado, que no se parecÃ­a a ninguno de la tripulaciÃ³n, subiendo la escalera de la cÃ¡mara y caminando hacia adelante sobre cubierta, para luego desaparecer. Lo siguiÃ³ cautelosamente, pero cuando llegÃ³ cerca de la proa no encontrÃ³ a nadie, y todas las escotillas estaban cerradas. Le entrÃ³ un miedo pÃ¡nico supersticioso, y temo que ese pÃ¡nico pueda contagiarse a los demÃ¡s. AdelantÃ¡ndome, hoy harÃ© que registren todo el barco cuidadosamente, de proa a popa.
es_translation: On July 17, yesterday, one of the men, Olgaren, came to my cabin and in a confidential and fearful manner told me that he thought there was a strange man on board the ship. He narrated that during his watch he had been hiding behind the deckhouse, as there was a stormy rain, when he saw a tall, thin man, who did not resemble any of the crew, climbing the deckhouse ladder and walking forward on the deck, only to disappear. He followed him cautiously, but when he reached near the bow he found no one, and all the hatches were closed. A superstitious panic seized him, and I fear that this panic may spread to the others. Anticipating this, today I will have the entire ship carefully searched, from bow to stern.

tr_translation: One day before July 17, one of the men, Olgaren, came to my cabin and explained in fear that he believed there was a stranger on the ship. During his watch, when he took shelter behind the wheelhouse because of a rainstorm, he saw a tall, thin man who did not resemble any of the crew members come out from the deck doorway and disappear as he walked along the deck. He had carefully watched the man and found no one when he reached the bow of the ship; all the hatchways were closed. He was seized by a fear based on superstition, and I am afraid this panic might spread. To quell it, I will carefully search the entire ship from top to bottom today.

vi_translation: On July 17th, yesterday, sailor Olgaren came to me and fearfully confided that he was thinking about a strange man on the ship. He said that during his watch, he had stood hiding behind the ship's bow to avoid the rising storm, and had accidentally seen a tall but gaunt man, unlike anyone among us, appear on the deck, walk quickly towards the bow, and suddenly disappear. He followed, but when he reached the bow, he saw no one there; all the deck doors were still locked. Standing in front of me, the sailor's fear had not lessened at all; I feared that his panic would spread to the entire crew. To reassure them, today I had to search every nook and cranny of the ship.

en: Early in the morning we both got up and went down to the harbour to see if anything had happened in the night. There were very few people about, and though the sun was bright, and the air clear and fresh, the big, grim-looking waves, that seemed dark themselves because the foam that topped them was like snow, forced themselves in through the narrow mouth of the harbourâ€”like a bullying man going through a crowd. Somehow I felt glad that Jonathan was not on the sea last night, but on land. But, oh, is he on land or sea? Where is he, and how? I am getting fearfully anxious about him. If I only knew what to do, and could do anything!
es: Temprano esta maÃ±ana nos levantamos las dos y bajamos hasta el puerto para ver si habÃ­a sucedido algo durante la noche. HabÃ­a muy poca gente en los alrededores, y aunque el sol estaba brillando y el aire estaba claro y fresco, las grandes olas amenazantes, que parecÃ­an mÃ¡s oscuras de lo que eran debido a que la espuma las coronaba con penachos de nieve, se abrÃ­an paso a travÃ©s de la estrecha boca del puerto, como un hombre que camina a codazos entre una multitud. Sin razÃ³n aparente me sentÃ­ contenta de que Jonathan no hubiera estado en el mar, sino en tierra. Pero, Â¡oh!, Â¿estÃ¡ en tierra o en mar? Â¿DÃ³nde estÃ¡ Ã©l, y cÃ³mo? Me estoy poniendo verdaderamente ansiosa por su paradero. Â¡Si sÃ³lo supiera lo que debo hacer, y si pudiera hacer algo!
es_translation: Early this morning, the two of us got up and went down to the port to see if anything had happened during the night. There were very few people around, and although the sun was shining and the air was clear and fresh, the great threatening waves, which seemed darker than they were because the foam crowned them with plumes of snow, made their way through the narrow mouth of the port, like a man elbowing his way through a crowd. For no apparent reason, I felt glad that Jonathan had not been at sea, but on land. But, oh! Is he on land or at sea? Where is he, and how is he? I am becoming truly anxious about his whereabouts. If only I knew what I should do, and if I could do something!

KeÅŸke ne yapacaÄŸÄ±mÄ± bilsem ve elimden bir ÅŸey gelse!
tr_translation: In the morning, we both got up early and went to the harbor to see if anything had happened during the night. There were very few people around; despite the sun being bright and the air clear and clean, the waves, which looked dark because of the foam on their crests like snow, were forcing their way through the narrow mouth of the harbor like a bully pushing through a crowd. For some reason, I was glad that Jonathan was on land rather than at sea last night. But, oh, on land or at sea? Where and how? I am worried for him in fear. I wish I knew what to do and could do something!

vi_translation: The two of us woke up very early and curiously invited each other to the port to see what had happened last night. There was almost no one there, even though the sun had risen and the weather had somewhat cooled down again. The sky was still filled with heavy black clouds. I was delighted with the thought that Jonathan had not gone to sea last night. But did he really not go to sea? Was he still on land? Where was he, and how were things going? Why was I so worried about him? If only I knew what I should do, if only I could do something, my mind would be so much more at ease.

en: When I bent over her I could see that she was still asleep. Her lips were parted, and she was breathingâ€”not softly as usual with her, but in long, heavy gasps, as though striving to get her lungs full at every breath. As I came close, she put up her hand in her sleep and pulled the collar of her nightdress close around her throat. Whilst she did so there came a little shudder through her, as though she felt the cold. I flung the warm shawl over her, and drew the edges tight round her neck, for I dreaded lest she should get some deadly chill from the night air, unclad as she was. I feared to wake her all at once, so, in order to have my hands free that I might help her, I fastened the shawl at her throat with a big safety-pin; but I must have been clumsy in my anxiety and pinched or pricked her with it, for by-and-by, when her breathing became quieter, she put her hand to her throat again and moaned. When I had her carefully wrapped up I put my shoes on her feet and then began very gently to wake her. At first she did not respond; but gradually she became more and more uneasy in her sleep, moaning and sighing occasionally. At last, as time was passing fast, and, for many other reasons, I wished to get her home at once, I shook her more forcibly, till finally she opened her eyes and awoke. She did not seem surprised to see me, as, of course, she did not realise all at once where she was. Lucy always wakes prettily, and even at such a time, when her body must have been chilled with cold, and her mind somewhat appalled at waking unclad in a churchyard at night, she did not lose her grace. She trembled a little, and clung to me; when I told her to come at once with me home she rose without a word, with the obedience of a child. As we passed along, the gravel hurt my feet, and Lucy noticed me wince. She stopped and wanted to insist upon my taking my shoes; but I would not. However, when we got to the pathway outside the churchyard, where there was a puddle of water, remaining from the storm, I daubed my feet with mud, using each foot in turn on the other, so that as we went home, no one, in case we should meet any one, should notice my bare feet.
es: Cuando me inclinÃ© sobre ella pude ver que todavÃ­a dormÃ­a. Sus labios estaban abiertos, y ella estaba respirando, pero no con la suavidad acostumbrada sino a grandes y pesadas boqueadas, como si tratara de llenar plenamente sus pulmones a cada respiro. Al acercarme, subiÃ³ la mano y tirÃ³ del cuello de su camisÃ³n de dormir, como si sintiera frÃ­o. Sin embargo, siguiÃ³ dormida. Yo puse el caliente chal sobre sus hombros, amarrÃ¡ndole fuertemente las puntas alrededor del cuello, pues temÃ­a mucho que fuese a tomar un mortal resfrÃ­o del aire de la noche, asÃ­ casi desnuda como estaba. TemÃ­ despertarla de golpe, por lo que, para poder tener mis manos libres para ayudarla, le sujetÃ© el chal cerca de la garganta con un imperdible de gran tamaÃ±o; pero en mi ansiedad debo haber obrado torpemente y la pinchÃ© con Ã©l, porque al poco rato, cuando su respiraciÃ³n se hizo mÃ¡s regular, se llevÃ³ otra vez la mano a la garganta y gimiÃ³. Una vez que la hube envuelto cuidadosamente, puse mis zapatos en sus pies y comencÃ© a despertarla con mucha suavidad. En un principio no respondÃ­a: pero gradualmente se volviÃ³ mÃ¡s y mÃ¡s inquieta en su sueÃ±o, gimiendo y suspirando ocasionalmente. Por fin, ya que el tiempo pasaba rÃ¡pidamente y, por muchas otras razones, yo deseaba llevarla a casa de inmediato, la zarandeÃ© con mÃ¡s fuerza, hasta que finalmente abriÃ³ los ojos y despertÃ³. No pareciÃ³ sorprendida de verme, ya que, por supuesto, no se dio cuenta de inmediato de en dÃ³nde nos encontrÃ¡bamos. Lucy se despierta siempre con bella expresiÃ³n, e incluso en aquellos momentos, en que su cuerpo debÃ­a estar traspasado por el frÃ­o y su mente espantada al saber que habÃ­a caminado semidesnuda por el cementerio en la noche, no pareciÃ³ perder su gracia. TemblÃ³ un poco y me abrazÃ³ fuertemente; cuando le dije que viniera de inmediato conmigo de regreso a casa, se levantÃ³ sin decir palabra y me obedeciÃ³ como una niÃ±a. Al comenzar a caminar, la grava me lastimÃ³ los pies, y Lucy notÃ³ mi salto. Se detuvo y querÃ­a insistir en que me pusiera mis zapatos, pero yo me neguÃ©. Sin embargo, cuando salimos al sendero afuera del cementerio, donde habÃ­a un charco de agua, remanente de la tormenta, me untÃ© los pies con lodo usando cada vez un pie sobre el otro, para que al ir a casa, nadie, en caso de que encontrÃ¡ramos a alguien, pudiera notar mis pies descalzos.
es_translation: When I leaned over her, I could see that she was still asleep. Her lips were open, and she was breathing, but not with the usual softness; rather, in large and heavy gasps, as if she were trying to fully fill her lungs with each breath. As I approached, she raised her hand and pulled at the neck of her nightgown, as if she felt cold. However, she remained asleep. I placed the warm shawl over her shoulders, tying the ends tightly around her neck, as I was very afraid she might catch a deadly cold from the night air, being almost naked as she was. I feared waking her abruptly, so to have my hands free to help her, I fastened the shawl near her throat with a large safety pin; but in my anxiety, I must have acted clumsily and pricked her with it, because shortly after, when her breathing became more regular, she brought her hand to her throat again and moaned. Once I had carefully wrapped her, I put my shoes on her feet and began to wake her very gently. At first, she did not respond: but gradually she became more and more restless in her sleep, occasionally moaning and sighing. Finally, as time was passing quickly and for many other reasons, I wanted to take her home immediately, I shook her more forcefully until she finally opened her eyes and woke up. She did not seem surprised to see me, as, of course, she did not immediately realize where we were. Lucy always wakes up with a beautiful expression, and even at that moment, when her body must have been pierced by the cold and her mind terrified upon knowing she had walked semi-naked through the cemetery at night, she did not seem to lose her grace. She shivered a little and hugged me tightly; when I told her to come back home with me immediately, she got up without a word and obeyed me like a child. As we began to walk, the gravel hurt my feet, and Lucy noticed my jump. She stopped and wanted to insist that I put on my shoes, but I refused. However, when we reached the path outside the cemetery, where there was a puddle of water, a remnant of the storm, I smeared my feet with mud using one foot over the other, so that when we went home, no one, in case we met anyone, could notice my bare feet.

tr_translation: When I leaned over, I could see that she was still asleep. Her lips were parted and she was breathing - not softly as usual, but with long, deep breaths as if she wanted to fill her lungs completely with each inhale. When I approached her, she raised her hand in her sleep and wrapped the collar of her nightgown around her neck. As she did this, she shivered slightly as if she felt the cold. I threw a warm shawl over her and fastened the edges tightly around her neck because I was afraid she might catch a bad chill in the night air while she was so exposed. I was afraid of waking her suddenly, so I secured the shawl around her neck with a large safety pin to free my hands and help her; but in my anxious clumsiness, I must have pricked or stuck her with the pin because soon after, as her breathing calmed, she brought her hand to her neck and groaned once more. Once I had carefully wrapped her up, I put my shoes on her feet and then began to wake her gently. At first, she did not respond, but she became increasingly restless, occasionally groaning and sighing in her sleep. Time was passing quickly, and for many other reasons, I wanted to get her home as soon as possible; finally, I shook her with great effort until she opened her eyes and woke up. Of course, she did not seem surprised to see me because she did not immediately understand where she was. Lucy always wakes up beautifully, and even at such a time, when her body was chilled from the cold and her mind was somewhat horrified by waking up in the churchyard at night without her clothes, she did not lose her grace. She shivered a little and hugged me; when I told her to come home with me immediately, she stood up without saying a word, like an obedient child. As we walked, the gravel hurt my feet, and Lucy noticed the pained expression on my face. She stopped and wanted to insist that I take my shoes back, but I refused. But when we reached the goat path outside the churchyard, where there was a puddle left from the storm, I stepped into the mud with one foot after the other, so that if we encountered anyone on the way home, no one would notice my bare feet.

vi_translation: Lucy was sleeping very soundly, her lips slightly parted, her breathing not as smooth as usual. It seemed she was struggling with labored breaths to draw air into her chest. She stirred slightly and unconsciously pulled her nightgown up to cover her neck. I suddenly noticed she was shivering from head to toe. I gently wrapped my woolen scarf around her neck. However, it seemed my clumsy, frightened hand had jabbed her neck, as I saw her raise her hand to rub her neck and let out a soft moan. My long fingernail had hurt her, but she did not wake up because of it. After putting my shoes on her feet, I dared to gently wake her up. She let out another soft moan and exhaled deeply, but did not move any further. Realizing that a new day was approaching, which would make it inconvenient to take Lucy back to the hotel, I had to shake her a bit more firmly. Finally, she opened her eyes, but did not show any surprise upon seeing me, clearly still unaware of where she was. Even in her drowsy state, Lucy looked as beautiful as ever. Even though she had spent a cold, shivering night in a desolate graveyard, wearing only a nightgown, she had not lost her graceful charm. Even after waking up, she was still trembling. When I said, "Let's go home right away," she silently stood up and obediently followed like a child. On the way back, the gravel had bloodied my feet. Seeing this, she stopped and insisted that I put on the shoes I had given her. Of course, I refused. Upon leaving the cemetery, I had to dip both feet in mud so that if anyone saw us, they wouldn't notice I was barefoot.

en: Fortune favoured us, and we got home without meeting a soul. Once we saw a man, who seemed not quite sober, passing along a street in front of us; but we hid in a door till he had disappeared up an opening such as there are here, steep little closes, or â€œwynds,â€ as they call them in Scotland. My heart beat so loud all the time that sometimes I thought I should faint. I was filled with anxiety about Lucy, not only for her health, lest she should suffer from the exposure, but for her reputation in case the story should get wind. When we got in, and had washed our feet, and had said a prayer of thankfulness together, I tucked her into bed. Before falling asleep she askedâ€”even imploredâ€”me not to say a word to any one, even her mother, about her sleep-walking adventure. I hesitated at first to promise; but on thinking of the state of her motherâ€™s health, and how the knowledge of such a thing would fret her, and thinking, too, of how such a story might become distortedâ€”nay, infallibly wouldâ€”in case it should leak out, I thought it wiser to do so. I hope I did right. I have locked the door, and the key is tied to my wrist, so perhaps I shall not be again disturbed. Lucy is sleeping soundly; the reflex of the dawn is high and far over the sea....
es: La fortuna nos favoreciÃ³ y llegamos a casa sin encontrar un alma. En una ocasiÃ³n vimos a un hombre, que no parecÃ­a estar del todo sobrio, cruzÃ¡ndose por una calle enfrente de nosotros; pero nos escondimos detrÃ¡s de una puerta hasta que desapareciÃ³ por un campo abierto como los que abundan por aquÃ­, pequeÃ±os atrios inclinados, o winds, como los llaman en Escocia. Durante todo este tiempo mi corazÃ³n palpitÃ³ tan fuertemente que por momentos pensÃ© que me desmayarÃ­a. Estaba llena de ansiedad por Lucy, no tanto por su salud, a pesar de que podÃ­a afectarle el aire frÃ­o, sino por su reputaciÃ³n en caso de que la historia de lo sucedido se hiciera pÃºblica. Cuando entramos, y una vez que hubimos lavado nuestros pies y rezado juntas una oraciÃ³n de gracias, la metÃ­ en cama. Antes de quedarse dormida me pidiÃ³, me implorÃ³, que no dijese una palabra a nadie, ni siquiera a su madre, de lo que habÃ­a pasado aquella noche. Al principio dudÃ© de hacer la promesa; pero al pensar en el estado de salud de su madre, y cÃ³mo la excitarÃ­a la noticia de un acontecimiento como aquÃ©l, y pensando ademÃ¡s cÃ³mo podÃ­a ser retorcida aquella historia (no, serÃ­a infaliblemente falsificada) en caso de que fuese conocida, pensÃ© que era mÃ¡s cuerdo prometer lo que se me pedÃ­a. Espero que haya obrado bien. He cerrado la puerta y he atado la llave a mi muÃ±eca, por lo que tal vez no vuelva a ser perturbada. Lucy estÃ¡ durmiendo profundamente; el reflejo de la aurora aparece alto y lejos sobre el marâ€¦
es_translation: Fortune favored us and we arrived home without encountering a soul. On one occasion, we saw a man, who did not seem to be entirely sober, crossing a street in front of us; but we hid behind a door until he disappeared into an open field like the ones that abound here, small sloping courtyards, or winds, as they are called in Scotland. During all this time, my heart pounded so strongly that at times I thought I would faint. I was filled with anxiety for Lucy, not so much for her health, even though the cold air could affect her, but for her reputation in case the story of what happened became public. When we entered, and once we had washed our feet and prayed together a prayer of thanks, I put her to bed. Before falling asleep, she asked me, implored me, not to say a word to anyone, not even to her mother, about what had happened that night. At first, I hesitated to make the promise; but when I thought about her mother's state of health, and how the news of such an event would excite her, and also considering how that story could be twisted (no, it would infallibly be falsified) if it became known, I thought it was wiser to promise what was asked of me. I hope I have acted rightly. I have closed the door and tied the key to my wrist, so I may not be disturbed again. Lucy is sleeping deeply; the reflection of the dawn appears high and far over the seaâ€¦

tr_translation: Luck was on our side and we reached home without encountering anyone. Once, as we were moving along the road ahead, we saw a man who was not very sober; but we hid in the recess of a doorway until the man disappeared down one of the steep paths called wynds in Scotland. My heart was beating so fast that I thought I would faint at times. I was very worried about Lucy; not only for her health, fearing she might be harmed by being exposed, but also for her reputation if the story were to spread from ear to ear. After we went inside, washed our feet, and said a prayer of thanks together, I put her to bed. Before falling asleep, she asked me not to tell anyone, not even her mother, about this sleepwalking adventure, she even begged for it. At first, I hesitated to promise this; but when I thought about her mother's health and how learning about this would worry her, and how such a story could be distorted if it leaked out -no, it would definitely be distorted- I decided it was wiser to do as she asked. I hope I did the right thing. I locked the door; the key is tied to my hand so that perhaps I won't be disturbed again. Lucy is sleeping soundly; the reflection of dawn can be seen over the sea...

Hy vá»ng lÃ  tÃ´i Ä‘Ã£ lÃ m Ä‘Ãºng. TÃ´i khÃ³a cá»­a vÃ  cá»© tháº¿ giá»¯ chÃ¬a khÃ³a trong tay mÃ  Ä‘i náº±m. CÃ³ láº½ tÃ´i sáº½ khÃ´ng bá»‹ rÆ¡i vÃ o tÃ¬nh tháº¿ khÃ³ khÄƒn ná»¯a. Lucy láº¡i nhanh chÃ³ng chÃ¬m sÃ¢u vÃ o giáº¥c ngá»§. NgoÃ i kia, Ã¡nh bÃ¬nh minh Ä‘Ã£ láº¥p loÃ¡ng trÃªn máº·t biá»ƒn...
vi_translation: But luck smiled on Lucy and me: we made it home without encountering anyone. Actually, there was a man on his way to get fish, but we managed to hide by the church gate until he passed. Itâ€™s hardly worth mentioning that I was not only worried about Lucy catching a cold, but also deeply afraid of her reputation being tarnished if this incident came to light. Once home, after washing her feet, I immediately took her to her room. Before sleeping, she pleaded with me not to tell anyone, not even her mother. At first, I hesitated about whether to promise her, but after thinking it over, I decided to agree, as I was also concerned about her mother's health, knowing she would be shocked by the news. I hope I did the right thing. I locked the door and kept the key in my hand as I lay down. Perhaps I won't find myself in such a difficult situation again. Lucy quickly fell back into a deep sleep. Outside, the dawn light was glimmering on the sea...

en: 18 August.â€”I am happy to-day, and write sitting on the seat in the churchyard. Lucy is ever so much better. Last night she slept well all night, and did not disturb me once. The roses seem coming back already to her cheeks, though she is still sadly pale and wan-looking. If she were in any way anÃ¦mic I could understand it, but she is not. She is in gay spirits and full of life and cheerfulness. All the morbid reticence seems to have passed from her, and she has just reminded me, as if I needed any reminding, of that night, and that it was here, on this very seat, I found her asleep. As she told me she tapped playfully with the heel of her boot on the stone slab and said:â€”
es: 18 de agosto. Hoy estoy muy contenta, y escribo sentada en el asiento del cementerio de la iglesia. Lucy estÃ¡ mucho mejor. Anoche durmiÃ³ bien toda la noche, y no me molestÃ³ ni una vez. Parece que ya las rosas regresan a sus mejillas, aunque todavÃ­a estÃ¡ tristemente pÃ¡lida y descolorida. Yo entenderÃ­a su situaciÃ³n si estuviera anÃ©mica, pero no es el caso. EstÃ¡ de muy buen humor, y llena de vida y alegrÃ­a. Toda aquella mÃ³rbida reticencia parece haberla abandonado, y hace justamente un momento me recordÃ³, como si yo necesitara que me la recordaran, aquella noche, y lo que sucediÃ³ aquÃ­, en este mismo asiento, donde la encontrÃ© dormida. Al tiempo que me hablaba taconeaba juguetonamente con el tacÃ³n de su bota sobre la lÃ¡pida, y dijo:
es_translation: August 18th. Today I am very happy, and I am writing while sitting on the seat in the church cemetery. Lucy is much better. Last night she slept well all night, and did not bother me even once. It seems that the roses are returning to her cheeks, although she is still sadly pale and discolored. I would understand her situation if she were anemic, but that is not the case. She is in very good spirits, and full of life and joy. All that morbid reticence seems to have left her, and just a moment ago she reminded me, as if I needed reminding, of that night, and what happened here, on this very seat, where I found her asleep. As she spoke to me, she playfully tapped her boot heel on the tombstone, and said:

tr_translation: August 18. - Today I am happy and writing while sitting on a bench in the church garden. Lucy is much better. Last night, she slept well all night and did not disturb me even once. Although she still looks distressingly pale and exhausted, it is as if the roses have returned to her cheeks. If she had anemia, I could understand it, but she does not. Her spirits are high, full of life and joy. She seems to have moved away from all that frightening silence and, as if I needed reminding, she reminded me of that night and how I found her here, sleeping on this very bench. As she was telling me these things, she was joyfully tapping the stone slab on the ground with the heel of her boot:

vi_translation: â€¢ August 18 I am writing these lines while sitting on a cemetery bench. Today, Lucy seems to be better. Last night, she did not wake up even once. Although she is still pale and weak, her cheeks have a slight blush. She also seems happier, very happy indeed. She has shed her long-standing inexplicable gloom and even reminded me of the incident that happened the other night! As she spoke, she delightedly tapped her heel on the stone grave.

en: I am weary to-night and low in spirits. I cannot but think of Lucy, and how different things might have been. If I donâ€™t sleep at once, chloral, the modern Morpheusâ€”C2HCl3O. H2O! I must be careful not to let it grow into a habit. No, I shall take none to-night! I have thought of Lucy, and I shall not dishonour her by mixing the two. If need be, to-night shall be sleepless....

If I don't sleep immediately, chloral, the modern Morpheus: CHCl3CHO. I must be very careful not to get used to it. No, I won't take anything tonight! I've thought about Lucy, and I won't dishonor her by mixing her with the other. If it has to be this way, I'll spend the night awake...

If I don't sleep immediately, then chloral, the modern Morpheos25 - C2Cl3CH(OH)2! I must be careful not to let this become a habit. No, I will not take it tonight! I thought of Lucy and I should not mix this with thoughts of her, it would be disrespectful to Lucy. If necessary, I will spend this night sleepless...

vi_translation: Tonight I feel so exhausted, my body wilting like a withered leaf. The thought of Lucy continuously haunts me, and every time I think of her, I can't help but wonder if the situation might change? Tonight, if I can't quickly fall asleep after lying down, I might have to reluctantly take a newly developed sleeping pill - the type C2HCl3O. H2O. Of course, I must try not to let this become a habit. No, tonight I will definitely not use any sedatives. To be honest, I have thought a lot about Lucy, and I don't intend to erase the sweet memory of her at any cost. Tonight, I will once again not sleep.

en: 25 August.â€”Another bad night. Mother did not seem to take to my proposal. She seems not too well herself, and doubtless she fears to worry me. I tried to keep awake, and succeeded for a while; but when the clock struck twelve it waked me from a doze, so I must have been falling asleep. There was a sort of scratching or flapping at the window, but I did not mind it, and as I remember no more, I suppose I must then have fallen asleep. More bad dreams. I wish I could remember them. This morning I am horribly weak. My face is ghastly pale, and my throat pains me. It must be something wrong with my lungs, for I donâ€™t seem ever to get air enough. I shall try to cheer up when Arthur comes, or else I know he will be miserable to see me so.

es_translation: August 25. Another bad night. My mother didn't seem to fall for my proposal. She herself doesn't seem to be doing so well, and there's no doubt that she worries a lot about me. I tried to stay awake, and for a while I managed; but when the clock struck twelve, it woke me from a stupor, so I must have been dozing off. There were some kind of flapping and scratching at the window, but I didn't pay them any mind, and since I don't remember what happened next, I suppose I must have fallen asleep. More nightmares. How I wish I could remember them! This morning I felt terribly weak. My face is extremely pale, and my throat hurts. Something must be wrong with my lungs, as it seems I never inhale enough air. I will try to appear cheerful when Arthur arrives, because otherwise I know he will suffer greatly seeing me like this.

tr_translation: August 25. - Another bad night. My mother seemed unwilling to accept my offer. She doesn't look very well herself and undoubtedly fears worrying me. I tried to stay awake and managed to do so for a while; when the clock struck twelve, it woke me from my sleep, so I must have fallen asleep. There was a kind of scratching or flapping sound at the window, but I didn't pay any attention to it; I don't remember anything else, I think I must have fallen asleep at that moment. Nightmares again. I wish I could remember them. This morning, I am terribly weak. My face is deathly pale and my throat hurts. There must be something wrong with my lungs because it feels like I'm not getting enough air. I'll try to cheer up when Arthur arrives, otherwise, I know he'll be devastated to see me like this.

vi_translation: â€¢ August 25 Another terrible night. My suggestion seemed to have not pleased my mother. She herself was not feeling very well. Moreover, she was probably afraid of disturbing my sleep if we shared a room. So I still had to sleep in my own room, and in fact, I did get some sleep, but the long chime at midnight woke me up. I suddenly heard strange sounds like someone scratching at the door, or rather the flapping of wings. But I didn't wonder about it for long, and honestly, I don't remember anything else. I went back to sleep right after that. Again, nightmares. If only I could remember everything... In the morning, I felt terribly weak. My face was as pale as someone about to enter the grave, and I also felt pain in my neck... it seemed like there was a problem with my chest too, occasionally I found it very hard to breathe. But no matter what, I still tried to appear a bit cheerful in front of Arthur, otherwise, he would be very sad again.

en: 17 September.â€”I was engaged after dinner in my study posting up my books, which, through press of other work and the many visits to Lucy, had fallen sadly into arrear. Suddenly the door was burst open, and in rushed my patient, with his face distorted with passion. I was thunderstruck, for such a thing as a patient getting of his own accord into the Superintendentâ€™s study is almost unknown. Without an instantâ€™s pause he made straight at me. He had a dinner-knife in his hand, and, as I saw he was dangerous, I tried to keep the table between us. He was too quick and too strong for me, however; for before I could get my balance he had struck at me and cut my left wrist rather severely. Before he could strike again, however, I got in my right and he was sprawling on his back on the floor. My wrist bled freely, and quite a little pool trickled on to the carpet. I saw that my friend was not intent on further effort, and occupied myself binding up my wrist, keeping a wary eye on the prostrate figure all the time. When the attendants rushed in, and we turned our attention to him, his employment positively sickened me. He was lying on his belly on the floor licking up, like a dog, the blood which had fallen from my wounded wrist. He was easily secured, and, to my surprise, went with the attendants quite placidly, simply repeating over and over again: â€œThe blood is the life! The blood is the life!â€
es: 17 de septiembre. Estaba ocupado, despuÃ©s de cenar, en mi estudio fechando mis libros, los cuales, debido a la urgencia de otros trabajos y a las muchas visitas a Lucy, se encontraban tristemente atrasados. De pronto, la puerta se abriÃ³ de golpe y mi paciente entrÃ³ como un torbellino, con el rostro deformado por la ansiedad. Yo me sobresaltÃ©, pues es una cosa casi desconocida que un paciente entre de esa manera y por su propia cuenta en el despacho del superintendente. Sin embargo, fue demasiado rÃ¡pido y demasiado fuerte para mÃ­; antes de que yo pudiera alcanzar mi equilibrio me habÃ­a lanzado el primer golpe, cortÃ¡ndome bastante profundamente la muÃ±eca izquierda. Pero antes de que pudiera lanzarme otro golpe, le di un derechazo y cayÃ³ con los brazos y piernas extendidos por el suelo. Mi muÃ±eca sangraba profusamente, y un pequeÃ±o charco se formÃ³ sobre la alfombra. Vi que mi amigo no parecÃ­a intentar otro esfuerzo, por lo que me ocupÃ© en vendar mi muÃ±eca, manteniendo todo el tiempo una cautelosa vigilancia sobre la figura postrada. Cuando mis asistentes entraron corriendo y pusimos nuestra atenciÃ³n sobre Ã©l, su aspecto positivamente me enfermÃ³. Estaba acostado sobre el vientre en el suelo, lamiendo como un perro la sangre que habÃ­a caÃ­do de mi muÃ±eca herida. Lo sujetamos con facilidad, y, para sorpresa mÃ­a, se dejÃ³ llevar con bastante docilidad por los asistentes, repitiendo una y otra vez: â€“Â¡La sangre es la vida! Â¡La sangre es la vida!
es_translation: September 17th. I was busy, after dinner, in my study dating my books, which, due to the urgency of other work and the many visits to Lucy, were sadly behind. Suddenly, the door burst open and my patient entered like a whirlwind, his face distorted with anxiety. I was startled, as it is almost unheard of for a patient to enter in such a manner and on their own into the superintendent's office. Without any pause, he headed directly towards me. In his hand was a kitchen knife, and seeing that it was dangerous, I tried to keep the table between us. However, he was too quick and too strong for me; before I could regain my balance, he had struck the first blow, cutting my left wrist quite deeply. But before he could strike me again, I punched him with my right hand and he fell to the floor with his arms and legs spread out. My wrist was bleeding profusely, and a small pool formed on the carpet. I saw that my friend did not seem to be making another effort, so I focused on bandaging my wrist, all the while keeping a cautious watch on the prostrate figure. When my assistants came running in and we turned our attention to him, his appearance positively sickened me. He was lying on his stomach on the floor, licking like a dog the blood that had fallen from my wounded wrist. We restrained him easily, and to my surprise, he allowed himself to be taken away quite docilely by the assistants, repeating over and over: â€“"Blood is life!" "Blood is life!"

tr_translation: September 17 - After dinner, due to the pressure of other tasks and the numerous visits to Lucy, I unfortunately worked in my room to complete my remaining tasks. Suddenly, the door opened and my patient, whose face was contorted with anger, burst in. I was stunned, because it was almost unheard of for a patient to enter the Administrator's room of their own accord. Without hesitating for even a moment, he came directly at me. He had a dinner knife in his hand, and seeing that it was dangerous, I tried to keep the table between us. But he was far too fast and far too strong for me; thus, before I could regain my balance, he struck me with the knife and cut my left wrist quite seriously. However, before he could attack again, I lunged at him with my right hand and knocked him flat on his back. My wrist was bleeding heavily, forming a small pool on the carpet. Seeing that my friend had no intention of further struggle, I busied myself with bandaging my wrist without taking my eyes off the person lying on the ground. When the nurses rushed in and we turned our attention to him, what he was doing absolutely sickened me. Lying face down on the floor, like a dog, he was licking the blood that had dripped from my wounded wrist. He was easily caught and, to my surprise, went quite docilely with the nurses; as he left, he kept repeating these words: "The blood is the life! The blood is the life!"

vi_translation: â€¢ September 17 After finishing dinner, I returned to my room, planning to schedule the next few working days. Suddenly, my door burst open, followed by the abrupt appearance of Renfield: he charged straight at me with a very fierce expression. I stood there stunned, as it was very rare for a patient to unexpectedly seek out the head doctor without anyone's permission. He was brandishing a gleaming knife. I immediately realized that in his madness, he could become very dangerous, so I cautiously stepped back, intending to use the wooden table as a barrier between him and me. But he was quicker than I was; before I could regain my balance, he had already slashed my left wrist quite deeply. However, not allowing him to swing the knife a second time, I immediately lunged at him, pushing him flat onto the floor. Blood from the wound on my hand pooled into a small puddle on the carpet. Renfield remained lying still, seemingly not intending to attack again. It was only then that I had time to bandage my wound while keeping my eyes fixed on the patient. When the attendants arrived, we gathered around to lift him up and push him back to his room, but he started thrashing and suddenly turned around to do something that astonished me once again: he crawled on the floor like a dog and licked up the blood that had just dripped from my wound. As he licked, he kept muttering the same phrase over and over: â€œBlood is life? Blood is life!â€

en: The time did not seem long, but very, very awful, till I recovered consciousness again. Somewhere near, a passing bell was tolling; the dogs all round the neighbourhood were howling; and in our shrubbery, seemingly just outside, a nightingale was singing. I was dazed and stupid with pain and terror and weakness, but the sound of the nightingale seemed like the voice of my dead mother come back to comfort me. The sounds seemed to have awakened the maids, too, for I could hear their bare feet pattering outside my door. I called to them, and they came in, and when they saw what had happened, and what it was that lay over me on the bed, they screamed out. The wind rushed in through the broken window, and the door slammed to. They lifted off the body of my dear mother, and laid her, covered up with a sheet, on the bed after I had got up. They were all so frightened and nervous that I directed them to go to the dining-room and have each a glass of wine. The door flew open for an instant and closed again. The maids shrieked, and then went in a body to the dining-room; and I laid what flowers I had on my dear motherâ€™s breast. When they were there I remembered what Dr. Van Helsing had told me, but I didnâ€™t like to remove them, and, besides, I would have some of the servants to sit up with me now. I was surprised that the maids did not come back. I called them, but got no answer, so I went to the dining-room to look for them.
es: No pareciÃ³ transcurrir mucho rato, sino mÃ¡s bien que fue muy, muy terrible, hasta que pude recobrar nuevamente la conciencia. En algÃºn lugar cercano, una campana doblaba; todos los perros de la vecindad estaban aullando, y en nuestros arbustos, aparentemente muy cercanos, cantaba un ruiseÃ±or. Yo estaba aturdida y embotada de dolor, terror y debilidad, pero el sonido del ruiseÃ±or pareciÃ³ la voz de mi madre muerta que regresaba para consolarme. Los ruidos parece que tambiÃ©n despertaron a las sirvientas, pues pude oÃ­r sus pisadas descalzas corriendo fuera de mi puerta. Las llamÃ© y entraron, y cuando vieron lo que habÃ­a sucedido, y quÃ© era lo que descansaba sobre mÃ­ en la cama, dieron gritos. El viento irrumpiÃ³ a travÃ©s de la rota ventana y la puerta se cerrÃ³ de golpe. Levantaron el cuerpo de mi amada madre y la acostaron, cubriÃ©ndola con una sÃ¡bana, sobre la cama, despuÃ©s de que yo me hube levantado. Estaban tan asustadas y nerviosas que les ordenÃ© fueran al comedor a tomar cada una un vaso de vino. La puerta se abriÃ³ de golpe unos instantes y luego se cerrÃ³ otra vez. Las sirvientas gritaron horrorizadas, y luego se fueron en grupo compacto al comedor, y yo puse las flores que habÃ­a tenido alrededor de mi cuello sobre el pecho de mi querida madre. Cuando ya estaban allÃ­ recordÃ© lo que me habÃ­a dicho el doctor van Helsing, pero no quise retirarlas, y, ademÃ¡s, alguna de las sirvientas podrÃ­a sentarse conmigo ahora. Me sorprendiÃ³ que las criadas no regresaran. Las llamÃ©, pero no obtuve respuesta, por lo que bajÃ© al comedor a buscarlas.
es_translation: It did not seem to take long, but rather it was very, very terrible, until I could regain consciousness again. Somewhere nearby, a bell was tolling; all the neighborhood dogs were howling, and in our bushes, seemingly very close, a nightingale was singing. I was dazed and dulled by pain, terror, and weakness, but the sound of the nightingale seemed like the voice of my dead mother returning to comfort me. The noises also seemed to wake the maids, as I could hear their bare footsteps running outside my door. I called them and they came in, and when they saw what had happened, and what was lying on me in the bed, they screamed. The wind burst through the broken window and the door slammed shut. They lifted the body of my beloved mother and laid her, covering her with a sheet, on the bed after I had gotten up. They were so scared and nervous that I ordered them to go to the dining room and each have a glass of wine. The door burst open for a few moments and then closed again. The maids screamed in horror, and then they went in a tight group to the dining room, and I placed the flowers I had had around my neck on my dear mother's chest. When they were already there, I remembered what Dr. Van Helsing had told me, but I did not want to remove them, and besides, one of the maids could sit with me now. I was surprised that the maids did not return. I called them, but received no response, so I went down to the dining room to look for them.

tr_translation: The time it took for me to regain consciousness wasn't long, but it felt very, very terrifying. A bell was ringing somewhere nearby; all the dogs in the vicinity were howling, and a nightingale was singing in the thicket just outside. I was stunned and bewildered with pain, horror, and weakness, but the nightingale's voice was like the voice of my dead mother who had come back to comfort me. The voice seemed to have awakened the servants too, because I could hear the sound of their bare feet outside my door. I called out to them, they came in, and when they realized what was lying in my bed, they screamed in terror. The wind blew in through the window and the door slammed shut. They lifted my dear mother's corpse and, after I got up, they laid her on the bed and covered her. They were so frightened and tense that I ordered them to go to the dining room and have a glass of wine each. The door opened for a moment and then closed again. The servants screamed and all went to the dining room together; I laid all my flowers on my mother's chest. While they were there, I remembered what Dr. Van Helsing had told me, but I didn't want to move them, and besides, I was going to ask some of the servants to stay with me through the night. I was surprised that the servants did not return. I called out to them, but received no answer, so I went to the dining room to look for them.

vi_translation: Although I had only fainted for a short time, I was still very vague about the terrifying moments that had passed. When I regained consciousness, the first sound that reached my ears was the distant ringing of a death knell, followed by the barking of dogs around the house, and from the bushes in the garden, not far from my window, came the melodious singing of a nightingale. Sorrow, fear, and severe health deterioration all seemed to come at once, leaving me as lifeless as a dead person. However, hearing the nightingale's song, I felt as if I were hearing my mother's beloved voice, gently speaking in the dark to comfort me. Surely the strange noise had awakened the servants in the house, because I could clearly hear their bare footsteps softly stepping on the stair landing. Hearing my faint call, they quickly stepped into the room. They all screamed in fear; it goes without saying how terrified they were when they realized the misfortune that had befallen us and saw my mother lying on top of me. The wind blowing through the broken window occasionally made the door creak. The brave girls gathered around to move my mother aside so I could sit up. Knowing they were very emotional, I told them to go down to the dining room and have a sip of wine to calm down. They opened the door and then slammed it shut immediately after stepping out of the room. I could still hear them exclaim once more, followed by the sound of hurried footsteps rushing down the stairs. At that moment, I didn't know what to do except painfully pick up the flowers to place on my mother's chest and recall Professor Van Helsing's instructions, but remembering was just for the sake of remembering, as I no longer needed these flowers for anything. I anxiously waited for the servants to return: we would keep vigil together. But they did not return. I called out: no one answered. Finding it strange, I decided to grope my way down to the dining room.

en: Presently she woke, and I gave her food, as Van Helsing had prescribed. She took but a little, and that languidly. There did not seem to be with her now the unconscious struggle for life and strength that had hitherto so marked her illness. It struck me as curious that the moment she became conscious she pressed the garlic flowers close to her. It was certainly odd that whenever she got into that lethargic state, with the stertorous breathing, she put the flowers from her; but that when she waked she clutched them close. There was no possibility of making any mistake about this, for in the long hours that followed, she had many spells of sleeping and waking and repeated both actions many times.
es: Al poco rato despertÃ³, y yo le di alimentos tal como los habÃ­a prescrito van Helsing. SÃ³lo tomÃ³ unos pocos, y de mala gana. ParecÃ­a que ya no estaba con ella su antigua inconsciente lucha por la vida, y la fortaleza que hasta entonces habÃ­a marcado su enfermedad. Me sorprendiÃ³ como un hecho curioso el que en el momento de volverse consciente ella apretara las flores de ajo contra su pecho. Ciertamente era muy raro que cuando quiera que ella entrara a ese estado letÃ¡rgico, con respiraciÃ³n estertÃ³rea, tratara de quitarse las flores, pero que al despertar las sujetara. No habÃ­a ninguna posibilidad de cometer un error acerca de esto, pues en las largas horas que siguieron tuvo muchos perÃ­odos de sueÃ±o y vigilia, y repitiÃ³ ambas acciones muchas veces.
es_translation: Shortly after, she woke up, and I gave her food just as van Helsing had prescribed. She only took a little, and reluctantly. It seemed that her former unconscious struggle for life, and the strength that had marked her illness until then, were no longer with her. I was surprised by the curious fact that at the moment she became conscious, she pressed the garlic flowers against her chest. It was certainly very strange that whenever she entered that lethargic state, with stertorous breathing, she tried to remove the flowers, but upon waking, she held onto them. There was no possibility of making a mistake about this, for in the long hours that followed, she had many periods of sleep and wakefulness, and repeated both actions many times.

Bu konuda hata yapmanÄ±n olasÄ±lÄ±ÄŸÄ± yoktu, Ã§Ã¼nkÃ¼ takip eden uzun saatler iÃ§inde Ã§ok sayÄ±da uyku ve uyanma dÃ¶nemi geÃ§irdi ve bu iki eylemi de Ã§ok kere yineledi.
tr_translation: She woke up a little later and I gave her the meal prescribed by Van Helsing. She ate very little and was reluctant. There seemed to be no sign of the struggle for life and strength that had been indicative of her illness until now. It struck me as odd that as soon as she regained consciousness, she pressed the garlic flowers to her chest. It was certainly strange that whenever she fell into that state of sleep with labored breathing, she pushed the flowers away, but when she woke up, she clung to them tightly. There was no possibility of making a mistake in this matter, because she went through many periods of sleep and wakefulness over the long hours that followed, and she repeated these two actions many times.

vi_translation: After lying for a while longer, she woke up. I tried to feed her a little as per Van Helsing's instructions, but she ate as if enduring a torture! Despite the fact that even her unconscious instinctive strength had now abandoned her, it seemed there was still something urging her to fight to the end against the illness and to conquer it at all costs. I was truly surprised to see that as soon as she woke up, she hurriedly clutched the garlic wreath. I found this very strange: every time she fell into a deep sleep, making her breathing very labored, she would push the wreath away. Conversely, every time she woke up or was about to wake up, I saw her clutch the wreath tightly to herself. There was one more thing I couldn't mistake: in the hours that followed, I saw her wake up and then fall back into a deep sleep many times, and this kept happening with the same actions from her.

en: THE funeral was arranged for the next succeeding day, so that Lucy and her mother might be buried together. I attended to all the ghastly formalities, and the urbane undertaker proved that his staff were afflictedâ€”or blessedâ€”with something of his own obsequious suavity. Even the woman who performed the last offices for the dead remarked to me, in a confidential, brother-professional way, when she had come out from the death-chamber:â€”

es_translation: The funeral was arranged for the following day, so that Lucy and her mother could be buried together. I took care of all the unpleasant formalities, and the courteous funeral director proved to me that his employees were affected, or blessed, by some of his own gratuitous gentleness. Even the woman who performed the last rites for the dead commented to me, in a confidential manner, as if between colleagues, when she had left the death chamber:

When she stepped out of Lucy's room, she even confided in me with a very professional tone:

es_translation: â€“And now, friend John, I think we can go to bed. We want to sleep, both you and I, and rest to recover. Tomorrow we will both have a lot to do, but for tonight there is no need for us.

en: He was very pale, and his eyes seemed bulging out as, half in terror and half in amazement, he gazed at a tall, thin man, with a beaky nose and black moustache and pointed beard, who was also observing the pretty girl. He was looking at her so hard that he did not see either of us, and so I had a good view of him. His face was not a good face; it was hard, and cruel, and sensual, and his big white teeth, that looked all the whiter because his lips were so red, were pointed like an animalâ€™s. Jonathan kept staring at him, till I was afraid he would notice. I feared he might take it ill, he looked so fierce and nasty. I asked Jonathan why he was disturbed, and he answered, evidently thinking that I knew as much about it as he did: â€œDo you see who it is?â€
es: Estaba muy pÃ¡lido, y sus ojos parecÃ­an salirse de sus Ã³rbitas, mientras, con una mezcla de terror y asombro, miraba fijamente a un hombre alto y delgado, de nariz aguileÃ±a, bigote negro y barba en punta, que tambiÃ©n estaba observando a la muchacha bonita. La estaba mirando tan embebido que no se percatÃ³ de nuestra presencia, y por ello pude echarle un buen vistazo. Su cara no era una buena cara; era dura y cruel, y sensual, y sus grandes dientes blancos, que se miraban mÃ¡s blancos por el encendido rojo de sus labios, estaban afilados como los de un animal. Jonathan estuvo mirÃ¡ndolo tan fijamente que yo tuve hasta miedo de que el individuo lo notara. Y temÃ­ que lo tomara a mal, ya que se veÃ­a tan fiero y detestable. Le preguntÃ© a Jonathan por quÃ© estaba perturbado, y Ã©l me respondiÃ³, pensando evidentemente que yo sabÃ­a tanto como Ã©l cuando lo hizo:
es_translation: He was very pale, and his eyes seemed to be popping out of their sockets, while, with a mixture of terror and astonishment, he stared fixedly at a tall, thin man with an aquiline nose, black mustache, and pointed beard, who was also observing the pretty girl. He was looking at her so intently that he didn't notice our presence, and because of that, I was able to get a good look at him. His face was not a good face; it was hard and cruel, and sensual, and his large white teeth, which looked even whiter against the bright red of his lips, were sharp like an animal's. Jonathan was staring at him so fixedly that I was even afraid the individual would notice. And I feared he would take it badly, as he looked so fierce and detestable. I asked Jonathan why he was disturbed, and he replied, evidently thinking that I knew as much as he did when he answered:

tr_translation: He was very pale, and I saw that his eyes were bulging out of their sockets with a mix of half-terror and half-astonishment as he looked at the long, thin, hook-nosed man with a black mustache and a pointed beard who was watching that beautiful girl. The man was looking at the young girl so intently that he didn't see either of us, so I examined him closely. His face was not a good face; it was harsh, ruthless, and sensual, and his large white teeth, which appeared even whiter because his lips were excessively red, were pointed like those of an animal. Jonathan continued to look at him until he made me afraid that the man would notice. I feared that the man would misunderstand this, he looked very ruthless and rude. I asked Jonathan why he was disturbed, thinking I had as much knowledge about the matter as he did: â€œDo you see who he is?â€

vi_translation: For some reason, his face suddenly turned pale as if there wasn't a drop of blood left, and his eyes seemed to bulge out with bloodshot veins. It seemed like he was paying attention to a tall, skinny man with a hooked nose like a hawk's, a black mustache, and a long, sharp beard in front of him. And that man was also staring intently at the young girl. He was so engrossed in looking at the girl that he didn't notice anyone around him, allowing me to comfortably observe him. His face truly didn't convey anything good. It looked stiff, rough, and filled with lust, with the most frightening part being his large, white horse-like teeth. Between his lips, red as chili peppers,those teeth appeared as sharp as those of a wild animal. Jonathan still stared blankly at the strange man. Suddenly, I felt afraid of him, because he indeed had something very suspicious about him. When I asked why he was so dazed, Jonathan responded as if I had known everything all along:

en: 23 September.â€”Jonathan is better after a bad night. I am so glad that he has plenty of work to do, for that keeps his mind off the terrible things; and oh, I am rejoiced that he is not now weighed down with the responsibility of his new position. I knew he would be true to himself, and now how proud I am to see my Jonathan rising to the height of his advancement and keeping pace in all ways with the duties that come upon him. He will be away all day till late, for he said he could not lunch at home. My household work is done, so I shall take his foreign journal, and lock myself up in my room and read it....

He terminado mis quehaceres domÃ©sticos, por lo que tomarÃ© su diario extranjero y me encerrarÃ© en mi cuarto para leerloâ€¦
es_translation: September 23rd. Jonathan has improved after a bad night. I am glad that he has enough work to do, as it keeps his mind away from terrible things; and, oh, I am happy that he is no longer overwhelmed by the responsibility of his new position! I knew he would be true to himself, and now I am proud to see my Jonathan rising to the heights of his advanced position and keeping pace in every way with the duties that fall upon him. He will be out of the house all day until late, as he said he would not return for lunch. I have finished my household chores, so I will take his foreign journal and lock myself in my room to read itâ€¦
