tr_translation: September 23. - We had a bad night, but Jonathan is better now. I'm glad he has a lot of work to do because it keeps his mind off the dreadful things; I'm happy that he's not overwhelmed by the responsibilities that come with his new position. I knew he would return to his old self, and now seeing my Jonathan climb to the peak of his promotion and adapt to the responsibilities on his shoulders in every way makes me so proud. He will be out all day, until late, because he said he couldn't have lunch at home. My housework is done, so I can take the journal he kept abroad and lock myself in my room to read it...

vi_translation: â€¢ September 23 After a restless night, today, Jonathan seems to be doing better. I feel happy to see him working more, because only then will he stop overthinking. Indeed, I felt quite uplifted seeing him busy with new tasks, because I know he will prove to be worthy and capable of handling new responsibilities, no matter what they are! He was out all day and instructed not to have lunch at home. After finishing some small household chores, I nervously returned to my room to read the pages of the diary he had written during his journey to Transylvania...

en: â€œShe is one of Godâ€™s women, fashioned by His own hand to show us men and other women that there is a heaven where we can enter, and that its light can be here on earth. So true, so sweet, so noble, so little an egoistâ€”and that, let me tell you, is much in this age, so sceptical and selfish. And you, sirâ€”I have read all the letters to poor Miss Lucy, and some of them speak of you, so I know you since some days from the knowing of others; but I have seen your true self since last night. You will give me your hand, will you not? And let us be friends for all our lives.â€
es: â€“Ella es una de las mujeres de Dios, confeccionadas por sus propias manos para mostrarnos a los hombres y a otras mujeres que existe un cielo en donde podemos entrar, y que su luz puede estar aquÃ­ en la tierra. Tan veraz, tan dulce, tan noble, tan desinteresada, y eso, permÃ­tame decirle a usted, es mucho en esta edad tan escÃ©ptica y egoÃ­sta. Y usted, seÃ±or, he leÃ­do todas las cartas para la pobre seÃ±orita Lucy, y algunas de ellas hablan de usted, de tal manera que por medio del conocimiento de otros lo conozco a usted desde hace algunos dÃ­as; pero he conocido su verdadera personalidad desde anoche. Me darÃ¡ usted su mano, Â¿verdad que sÃ­? Y seamos amigos para toda la vida.
es_translation: â€“She is one of God's women, crafted by His own hands to show us men and other women that there is a heaven where we can enter, and that its light can be here on earth. So truthful, so sweet, so noble, so selfless, and that, allow me to tell you, is a lot in this very skeptical and selfish age. And you, sir, I have read all the letters to poor Miss Lucy, and some of them speak of you, in such a way that through the knowledge of others I have known you for some days; but I have known your true personality since last night. You will give me your hand, won't you? And let us be friends for life.

tr_translation: â€œOh, one of the women whom God has shaped with His own hands to show us other men and women that there can be a heaven we can go to, and that there can be light here on earth as well. So sincere, so sweet, so noble, so free from selfishness - this, let me tell you, is very important in an age as skeptical and selfish as ours. And you, sir - I have read all the letters written to poor Miss Lucy; some of them mentioned you, so I knew you before knowing others; but I learned your true character last night. You will give me your hand, won't you? Come, let us be friends for life.â€

vi_translation: â€” Your wife is truly a person of God. God created her with His own hands to show us that there really is a heaven on this earth, a heaven that one day His flock can ascend to. That heaven is indeed radiating its brilliant light down onto the bare life of this earth. A person with loyalty to God and to everyone, with kindness, gentleness, and the willingness to sacrifice everything for those around her like your wife, is not common in this century full of suspicion and selfishness. And you too, my friend. I have read all the letters your wife sent to Lucy, including the lines about you. Therefore, it is not just now that I know about you, but I truly understood you only since last evening. Come now, my friend, may I shake your hand? We will always be friends.

en: â€œYou are clever man, friend John; you reason well, and your wit is bold; but you are too prejudiced. You do not let your eyes see nor your ears hear, and that which is outside your daily life is not of account to you. Do you not think that there are things which you cannot understand, and yet which are; that some people see things that others cannot? But there are things old and new which must not be contemplate by menâ€™s eyes, because they knowâ€”or think they knowâ€”some things which other men have told them. Ah, it is the fault of our science that it wants to explain all; and if it explain not, then it says there is nothing to explain. But yet we see around us every day the growth of new beliefs, which think themselves new; and which are yet but the old, which pretend to be youngâ€”like the fine ladies at the opera. I suppose now you do not believe in corporeal transference. No? Nor in materialisation. No? Nor in astral bodies. No? Nor in the reading of thought. No? Nor in hypnotismâ€”â€”â€
es: â€“Usted es un hombre listo, amigo John; y tiene un ingenio agudo, pero tiene tambiÃ©n demasiados prejuicios. No deja usted que sus ojos vean y que sus oÃ­dos escuchen, y lo que estÃ¡ mÃ¡s allÃ¡ de su vida cotidiana no le interesa. Â¿No piensa usted que hay cosas que no puede comprender, y que sin embargo existen? Â¿QuÃ© algunas personas pueden ver cosas y que otras no pueden? Pero hay cosas antiguas y nuevas que no deben contempladas por los ojos de los hombres, porque ellos creen o piensan creer en cosas que otros hombres les han dicho. Â¡Ah, es error de nuestra ciencia querer explicarlo todo! Y si no puede explicarlo, dice que no hay nada que explicar. Pero usted ve alrededor de nosotros que cada dÃ­a crecen nuevas creencias, que se consideran a sÃ­ mismas nuevas, y que sin embargo son las antiguas, que pretenden ser jÃ³venes como las finas damas en la Ã³pera. Yo supongo que usted no cree en la transferencia corporal. Â¿No? Ni en la materializaciÃ³n. Â¿No? Ni en los cuerpos astrales. Â¿No? Ni en la lectura del pensamiento. Â¿No? Ni en el hipnotismoâ€¦
es_translation: â€“You are a clever man, friend John; and you have a sharp mind, but you also have too many prejudices. You do not let your eyes see and your ears hear, and what is beyond your daily life does not interest you. Do you not think that there are things you cannot understand, and yet they exist? That some people can see things and others cannot? But there are old and new things that should not be seen by the eyes of men, because they believe or think they believe in things that other men have told them. Ah, it is the error of our science to want to explain everything! And if it cannot explain it, it says there is nothing to explain. But you see around us that new beliefs grow every day, which consider themselves new, and yet they are the old ones, pretending to be young like the fine ladies at the opera. I suppose you do not believe in bodily transfer. No? Nor in materialization. No? Nor in astral bodies. No? Nor in thought reading. No? Nor in hypnotism...

tr_translation: â€œYou are a smart person, my friend John; you reason well and have a bold mind; but you are very prejudiced. You neither allow your eyes to see nor your ears to hear, and anything outside your daily life has no importance to you. Don't you believe that there are some things that exist even if you can't understand them, that some people see things that others cannot? But there are old and new things that people should not see with their eyes, because these people know what others have told them - or think they know. Ah, the flaw of our science is that it wants to explain everything; if it doesn't explain, it says there is nothing to explain. But every day we see new beliefs developing around us that consider themselves new; but in fact, these are old beliefs trying to appear new - just like the lovely ladies at the opera. I suppose you don't believe in matter transfer now. No? Nor in materialization. No? Nor in spirits. No? Nor in thought reading. No? Nor in hypnotism...â€

vi_translation: â€” You are very intelligent, John. You have very sound reasoning and are also very honest, but you have not avoided subjective prejudices. You don't pay attention to things, and clearly, that has not become a part of your daily life, so you never grasp anything for sure. Don't you think there are things in this world that, although you don't understand, still exist? And then some of us can see things that others cannot see! But to be fair, there are still many things in this world that people cannot understand because they either know or contemplate or perceive - those things are different from what they were taught. That's it! That is the flaw of science: science always wants to explain everything, and when it can't, it will declare that there is nothing to explain. However, we can see new theories every day, or rather, theories that claim to be new emerge somewhere, but in fact, they are just old theories dressed up to look new, like the beauties we see in theaters. Now, may I continue to ask, do you believe in the transformation of bodies? Will you answer no? You also don't believe in the theory of materialization? Also no? What about talismans? Yes or no? And the theory of mind reading? Again no?

en: â€œGood God, Professor!â€ I said, starting up. â€œDo you mean to tell me that Lucy was bitten by such a bat; and that such a thing is here in London in the nineteenth century?â€ He waved his hand for silence, and went on:â€”

vi_translation: â€” My God! Professor, are you saying that Lucy is the victim of some kind of bat? And here, in this city of London in the mid-nineteenth century, a similar thing could happen? He waved his hand to signal me to be quiet and continued:

en: â€œDr. Van Helsing, are you mad?â€ He raised his head and looked at me, and somehow the tenderness of his face calmed me at once. â€œWould I were!â€ he said. â€œMadness were easy to bear compared with truth like this. Oh, my friend, why, think you, did I go so far round, why take so long to tell you so simple a thing? Was it because I hate you and have hated you all my life? Was it because I wished to give you pain? Was it that I wanted, now so late, revenge for that time when you saved my life, and from a fearful death? Ah no!â€
es: â€“Doctor van Helsing, Â¿estÃ¡ usted loco? Ã‰l levantÃ³ la cabeza y me mirÃ³: la ternura que reflejaba su rostro me calmÃ³ de inmediato. â€“Â¡Me gustarÃ­a que asÃ­ fuera! â€“ dijo Ã©l-. Â¿Era porque yo querÃ­a, ahora, despuÃ©s de tanto tiempo, vengarme por aquella vez que usted salvÃ³ mi vida, y de una muerte terrible? Â¡Ah! Â¡No!.
es_translation: â€“Doctor van Helsing, are you crazy? He lifted his head and looked at me: the tenderness reflected in his face calmed me immediately. â€“I wish it were so! â€“ he said-. Madness would be easier to bear compared to truths like this. Oh, my friend! Why do you think I took such a long detour? Why did I take so much time to tell you something so simple? Is it because I hate you and have hated you all my life? Is it because I wanted to cause you harm? Was it because I wanted, now, after so much time, to take revenge for that time you saved my life, and from a terrible death? Ah! No!.

tr_translation: I slammed the table hard and stood up, saying: "Dr. Van Helsing, are you mad?" He looked up at me, and somehow the kindness on his face immediately calmed me. "I wish I were!" he said. "Madness is much easier to bear than such a truth. Oh, my friend, why do you think I beat around the bush, why did it take me so long to tell you something so simple? Because I hated you and have hated you all my life? Because I wanted to make you suffer? Because I wanted to take revenge, albeit late, for the time you saved my life, rescuing me from a horrific death? Oh, no!"

vi_translation: Van Helsing sat still, looking up at me, his kind eyes calming me immediately. â€” Oh Lord! - He said very slowly. - What a pity, I want to go mad but I can't! If I could go mad, it would be much easier to endure such a truth. Ah! My friend, why do you think I keep rambling on before confessing that very simple thing! Is it because I hate you as I have always treated you until now? Is it because I want you to suffer even more? Or is it that after all these years, I always intended to repay your life-saving act with those harsh words? No, absolutely not, isn't that right, my friend?

en: â€œI hope,â€ said Van Helsing, â€œthat when you are sending the child home you will caution its parents to keep strict watch over it. en: â€œMy Lord Godalming, I, too, have a duty to do, a duty to others, a duty to you, a duty to the dead; and, by God, I shall do it! en: â€œYou are quite right. I did not trust you because I did not know you. But I know you now; and let me say that I should have known you long ago. I know that Lucy told you of me; she told me of you too. May I make the only atonement in my power? Take the cylinders and hear themâ€”the first half-dozen of them are personal to me, and they will not horrify you; then you will know me better. Dinner will by then be ready. In the meantime I shall read over some of these documents, and shall be better able to understand certain things.â€ He carried the phonograph himself up to my sitting-room and adjusted it for me. Now I shall learn something pleasant, I am sure; for it will tell me the other side of a true love episode of which I know one side already....

vi_translation: - The reason I didn't trust you before was because I didn't know you, that's all. But now, we know each other. Actually, I've heard about you for a long time. I know that Lucy has mentioned me to you before; and she has also told me about you. Sorry! Now please take these tapes and listen. The first six tapes are all about me and of course, there's nothing in them that should concern you. You can listen to them or not, but if you do, you'll understand me better. Dinner is probably almost ready. As for me, I might have to read these documents to learn some additional details. He took the recording device to a small living room adjacent to my room and pressed play. I eagerly prepared to listen to the first diary entries that captured another aspect of the love story, which I had only vaguely known through Lucy's account.

en: 29 September.â€”After dinner I came with Dr. Seward to his study. He brought back the phonograph from my room, and I took my typewriter. He placed me in a comfortable chair, and arranged the phonograph so that I could touch it without getting up, and showed me how to stop it in case I should want to pause. Then he very thoughtfully took a chair, with his back to me, so that I might be as free as possible, and began to read. I put the forked metal to my ears and listened.

vi_translation: â€¢ September 29 After finishing dinner, I followed Dr. Seward into his study. He went to the room to get the gramophone, while I carried down the typewriter. He arranged a convenient spot for me on the couch so that I could type and operate the gramophone placed beside me. Then, he showed me how to stop the machine when I wanted to take a short break to rest. Once the seating arrangement was done, I turned on the machine to continue listening to his spoken diary entries.

If they haven't been taken from there since then, there should be fifty of them - according to Dr. Seward's journal, I have concerns about this.

vi_translation: No matter what, I am now certain of one thing: all the crates were shipped from Varna to Whitby by the Demeter ship and then transferred to the private Carfax church. There were fifty crates in total, and after reading Dr. Seward's journal, I fear that since then, at least a few of them must have been used already.

vi_translation: On the way home, I took the opportunity to tell him everything that had happened since he returned to the country, including the story of how my diary suddenly became useful when Mina typed it up and organized it in chronological order.

en: â€œAnd now for you, Madam Mina, this night is the end until all be well. You are too precious to us to have such risk. When we part to-night, you no more must question. We shall tell you all in good time. We are men and are able to bear; but you must be our star and our hope, and we shall act all the more free that you are not in the danger, such as we are.â€
es: "Ahora, en cuanto a usted, seÃ±ora Mina, esta noche es el fin, hasta que todo vaya bien. Nos es usted demasiado preciosa para correr riesgos semejantes. Cuando nos separemos esta noche, usted no deberÃ¡ ya volver a hacernos preguntas. Se lo explicaremos todo a su debido tiempo. Nosotros somos hombres, y estamos en condiciones de soportarlo, pero usted debe ser nuestra estrella y esperanza, y actuaremos con mayor libertad si no se encuentra usted en peligro, como nosotros.
es_translation: "Now, as for you, Mrs. Mina, tonight is the end, until everything goes well. You are too precious to us to take such risks. When we part tonight, you must no longer ask us questions. We will explain everything to you in due time. We are men, and we are in a position to endure it, but you must be our star and hope, and we will act with greater freedom if you are not in danger, like us."

When we part tonight, you must ask no more questions. We will tell you everything in due time. We are men and can endure; but you must be our star, our hope, and we will move more freely when you are not in danger like us.â€

vi_translation: As for you, Harker, you will not need to worry about anything from now until everything is over. To us, you are very precious, so you cannot expose yourself to the countless dangers that lie ahead. Tonight, you do not need to ask us any more questions. We promise to tell you everything at an appropriate time. We men can endure the harshest trials, but you, our lucky star and hope, must always be kept safe from all dangers.

en: The morning was quickening in the east when we emerged from the front. Dr. Van Helsing had taken the key of the hall-door from the bunch, and locked the door in orthodox fashion, putting the key into his pocket when he had done.

es_translation: The glow of dawn was breaking from the east when we went out through the main door. Dr. Van Helsing had taken the key to the front door from the bunch, carefully closed it, put the key in his pocket, and turned to us.

tr_translation: When we stepped out the door, the day was coming to life from the east. Dr. Van Helsing had taken the key to the hall door from the bunch, and after properly locking the door and finishing his task, he put the key in his pocket.

vi_translation: When we went out the gate of the house, it was also when a new day was about to begin. Van Helsing carefully locked the door and put the key in his pocket. I do not know when he removed this key from the key ring in the house. â€” Good! - He said. -

en: I came tiptoe into our own room, and found Mina asleep, breathing so softly that I had to put my ear down to hear it. She looks paler than usual. I hope the meeting to-night has not upset her. I am truly thankful that she is to be left out of our future work, and even of our deliberations. It is too great a strain for a woman to bear. I did not think so at first, but I know better now. Therefore I am glad that it is settled. There may be things which would frighten her to hear; and yet to conceal them from her might be worse than to tell her if once she suspected that there was any concealment. Henceforth our work is to be a sealed book to her, till at least such time as we can tell her that all is finished, and the earth free from a monster of the nether world. I daresay it will be difficult to begin to keep silence after such confidence as ours; but I must be resolute, and to-morrow I shall keep dark over to-nightâ€™s doings, and shall refuse to speak of anything that has happened. I rest on the sofa, so as not to disturb her.
es: EntrÃ© en mi habitaciÃ³n de puntillas y encontrÃ© a Mina dormida, respirando con tanta suavidad que tuve que aguzar el oÃ­do para captar el sonido. ParecÃ­a mÃ¡s pÃ¡lida que de costumbre. Esperaba que la reuniÃ³n de aquella noche no la hubiera impresionado demasiado. Me siento verdaderamente agradecido de que permanezca fuera de nuestro trabajo futuro e incluso de nuestras deliberaciones. Es una tensiÃ³n demasiado grande para que la soporte una mujer. No pensaba asÃ­ al principio, pero ahora sÃ© mucho mejor a quÃ© atenerme. Por consiguiente, me alegro de que eso haya sido resuelto. Es posible que haya cosas que la asustaran si las oyera, no obstante, ocultÃ¡rselas serÃ­a peor que revelÃ¡rselas, si es que llega a sospechar que hay algo que no le decimos. A partir de este momento, tendremos que ser para ella como libros cerrados, por lo menos hasta el momento en que podamos anunciarle que todo ha concluido y que la tierra ha sido liberada de aquel monstruo de las tinieblas. Supongo que serÃ¡ difÃ­cil guardar silencio, debido a la confianza que reina entre nosotros, pero debo continuar en mi resoluciÃ³n y silenciar completamente todo lo relativo a nuestros actos durante aquella noche, negÃ¡ndome a hablar de lo que ha sucedido. Me acostÃ© sobre el divÃ¡n, para no molestarla.
es_translation: I entered my room on tiptoe and found Mina asleep, breathing so softly that I had to strain my ears to catch the sound. She seemed paler than usual. I hoped that the meeting that night had not impressed her too much. I feel truly grateful that she remains out of our future work and even our deliberations. It is too great a strain for a woman to bear. I did not think so at first, but now I know much better what to expect. Therefore, I am glad that this has been resolved. There may be things that would frighten her if she heard them; however, hiding them from her would be worse than revealing them, if she comes to suspect that there is something we are not telling her. From this moment on, we must be like closed books to her, at least until we can announce that everything is over and that the land has been freed from that monster of the darkness. I suppose it will be difficult to keep silent, due to the trust that reigns between us, but I must continue in my resolution and completely silence everything related to our actions during that night, refusing to speak of what has happened. I lay down on the divan, so as not to disturb her.

Bundan bÃ¶yle gÃ¶revimiz, en azÄ±ndan, ona her ÅŸeyin sona erdiÄŸini ve dÃ¼nyanÄ±n, cehennemden gelen bir canavardan kurtulduÄŸunu sÃ¶yleyebileceÄŸimiz zaman gelene dek onun iÃ§in mÃ¼hÃ¼rlÃ¼ bir kitap olmalÄ±. tr_translation: When I tiptoed into our room, Mina was asleep; she was breathing so softly that I had to lean in to hear it. She looks paler than usual. I hope tonight's meeting hasn't upset her. I'm grateful that she is kept out of our future work and even our own discussions. This is too much tension for a woman to bear. I didn't think so at first, but now I understand better. Therefore, I am glad that it was decided this way. There might be things she would be afraid to hear; yet, if she suspects there is a secret, hiding it from her could be worse than telling it. From now on, our duty, at the very least, should be to remain a sealed book to her until the time comes when we can tell her that everything is over and the world is rid of a monster from hell. I think it will be hard to start keeping silent after the trust between us, but I will act decisively and tomorrow, I will not reveal any secrets about what happened tonight and will refuse to talk about it. I'm sleeping on the couch so as not to disturb her.

vi_translation: I tiptoed back to the room. Mina was still deep in sleep, her breathing so slow and light that I had to lean in close to hear it. Only at this moment did I suddenly notice that she looked paler than usual. I hope yesterday's meeting didn't make her worry too much! Thankfully, she no longer participates in our investigations, searches, or decisions. She might get scared if she heard us discussing certain things. However, who knows if our keeping things from her might cause her even more distress if, at some point, she starts to suspect that we want her to stay silent about one thing or another. It is possible that in the near future, we will strive to ensure that you have absolutely no doubts about our decisions and work - at least until we can inform you that the bloodthirsty demon has been permanently eradicated from this earth. For me, keeping silent is not an easy task, especially when the two of us have the habit of sharing everything with each other. But I have decided, when she wakes up, I will definitely not tell her anything about what happened during the night. If she insists on asking, I will just mumble to brush it off. The sky was about to fully brighten, I tiptoed to lie down on the couch to avoid disturbing her sleep.

en: 1 October.â€”It is strange to me to be kept in the dark as I am to-day; after Jonathanâ€™s full confidence for so many years, to see him manifestly avoid certain matters, and those the most vital of all. This morning I slept late after the fatigues of yesterday, and though Jonathan was late too, he was the earlier. He spoke to me before he went out, never more sweetly or tenderly, but he never mentioned a word of what had happened in the visit to the Countâ€™s house. And yet he must have known how terribly anxious I was. Poor dear fellow! I suppose it must have distressed him even more than it did me. They all agreed that it was best that I should not be drawn further into this awful work, and I acquiesced. But to think that he keeps anything from me! And now I am crying like a silly fool, when I know it comes from my husbandâ€™s great love and from the good, good wishes of those other strong men.
es: 1 de octubre. Me resulta extraÃ±o permanecer en la oscuridad, como hoy; despuÃ©s de la confianza total de Jonathan durante tantos aÃ±os, me resulta desagradable verlo evitar ciertos temas de conversaciÃ³n de manera manifiesta: los temas mÃ¡s vitales de todos. Esta maÃ±ana dormÃ­ hasta una hora avanzada, a causa de las fatigas de ayer, y aunque Jonathan durmiÃ³ hasta tarde tambiÃ©n, despertÃ³ antes que yo. HablÃ³ conmigo antes de salir, y nunca antes lo habÃ­a hecho con mayor dulzura o ternura, pero no mencionÃ³ ni una sola palabra sobre lo que habÃ­a sucedido en su visita a la casa del conde. Sin embargo, debe saber la terrible ansiedad que sentÃ­a yo. Â¡Pobre Jonathan! Supongo que eso debe haberlo afligido todavÃ­a mÃ¡s que a mÃ­. Todos estuvieron de acuerdo en que no siguiera yo adelante en ese horrible asunto, y estuve de acuerdo. Pero, Â¡me resulta muy desagradable pensar que me oculta algo! Y ahora estoy llorando como una idiota, cuando, en realidad, sÃ© que todo esto es producto del gran amor de mi esposo y de la buena voluntad de todos esos hombres fuertes.
es_translation: October 1st. I find it strange to remain in the dark, like today; after Jonathan's total trust for so many years, it is unpleasant to see him openly avoid certain topics of conversation: the most vital topics of all. This morning I slept until a late hour, due to the fatigue of yesterday, and although Jonathan also slept late, he woke up before me. He spoke to me before leaving, and never before had he done so with greater sweetness or tenderness, but he did not mention a single word about what had happened during his visit to the count's house. However, he must know the terrible anxiety I felt. Poor Jonathan! I suppose that must have distressed him even more than it did me. Everyone agreed that I should not continue with that horrible matter, and I agreed. But, it is very unpleasant for me to think that he is hiding something from me! And now I am crying like an idiot, when, in reality, I know that all of this is a product of my husband's great love and the goodwill of all those strong men.

tr_translation: October 1st. - It feels strange to me not to be informed as I was today; after Jonathan's endless trust over the years, to avoid certain topics and the most crucial ones so openly! After yesterday's exhaustion, I slept in late this morning, and although Jonathan got up late as well, he was up earlier than me. Before leaving, he spoke to me in a sweeter and softer manner than ever before, but did not say a single word about what happened during the visit to the Count's house. But still, he must have known how worried I was. Poor dear man! I think this situation must have upset him even more than it upset me. They all decided together that I should not be drawn further into this dreadful matter, and I did not oppose it. But to think that he is hiding something from me! And now, even though I know it stems from my husband's great love and the good, good intentions of those other strong men, I am crying like a fool...

vi_translation: â€¢ October 1 I feel very upset being left out like today. For so many years, Jonathan has always shown great trust in me, but today, I had to meet him without knowing anything about their conversation. This morning, I woke up very late because I was extremely tired all day yesterday. Jonathan also woke up not long before noon, but he was still the first to wake up! Before leaving, he spoke to me in a gentler and more affectionate tone than ever, but he didn't mention a single word about the investigation of the old count's house last night. However, he surely understands that I am very worried about this matter. Poor him! Keeping silent will only make him more troubled because of me. They all unanimously decided to leave me out, and I can only accept it. But just thinking about my husband harboring many secrets from me makes me feel upset! Yet, I burst into tears like a child when I think that it's because of his love for me that he has to keep silent. And the rest of them too, they are gallant and kind friends who only want to ensure my health and safety!

en: That has done me good. Well, some day Jonathan will tell me all; and lest it should ever be that he should think for a moment that I kept anything from him, I still keep my journal as usual. Then if he has feared of my trust I shall show it to him, with every thought of my heart put down for his dear eyes to read. I feel strangely sad and low-spirited to-day. I suppose it is the reaction from the terrible excitement.
es: Eso me ha sentado bien. Me siento hoy extraÃ±amente triste y malhumorada. Supongo que es la reacciÃ³n a causa de la tremenda emociÃ³n.
es_translation: That has done me good. Well, someday Jonathan will tell me everything, and to avoid him thinking that I am also hiding something from him, I continue writing my diary, as usual. Thus, if he has doubted my trust, I must show it to him, including all the thoughts and feelings of my heart, so that he can read them clearly. Today I feel strangely sad and moody. I suppose it is the reaction due to the tremendous emotion.

Then, if he doubts my trust, I will show him every thought that comes from my heart written down, so that his dear eyes can read them. Today, I feel strangely sad and listless. It must be a reaction to that horrific excitement.

vi_translation: However, the hot tears rolling down my cheeks made me feel a bit relieved. I told myself that one day Jonathan would tell me everything. For now, I will continue to write my diary as usual. If he ever doubts my faith, I will let him know my feelings and thoughts through these diary entries. Just thinking about it, but today I still feel sad and weary. Perhaps this is also the consequence of my excessive emotions.

en: â€œLook â€™ere, guvâ€™nor, there ainâ€™t no sense in me a-keepinâ€™ you â€™ere. I may find Sam soon, or I maynâ€™t; but anyhow he ainâ€™t like to be in a way to tell ye much to-night. Sam is a rare one when he starts on the booze. If you can give me a envelope with a stamp on it, and put yer address on it, Iâ€™ll find out where Sam is to be found and post it ye to-night. But yeâ€™d better be up arter â€™im soon in the morninâ€™, or maybe ye wonâ€™t ketch â€™im; for Sam gets off main early, never mind the booze the night afore.â€
es: â€“Escuche, seÃ±or, no tiene sentido que espere usted aquÃ­. Es posible que encuentre pronto a Sam, o que no lo haga, pero, de todos modos, no creo que se encuentre en condiciones de decirle muchas cosas esta noche. Sam es un tipo raro cuando saca los pies de sus casillas. Si puede usted darme un sobre con un sello de correos y su direcciÃ³n, verÃ© donde es posible encontrar a Sam y le enviarÃ© los datos por correo esta misma noche. Pero serÃ¡ preciso que vaya a verlo muy de maÃ±ana si quiere encontrarlo, puesto que Sam se levanta temprano, por muy prolongada que haya sido la juerga de la noche anterior.
es_translation: â€“Listen, sir, it doesn't make sense for you to wait here. It's possible that you'll find Sam soon, or maybe you won't, but either way, I don't think he'll be in a condition to tell you much tonight. Sam is a strange guy when he gets upset. If you can give me an envelope with a postage stamp and your address, I'll see where I can find Sam and send you the information by mail tonight. But you'll need to go see him very early in the morning if you want to find him, since Sam gets up early, no matter how long the previous night's party lasted.

tr_translation: â€œListen, boss, there's no point in keeping you here. I might find Sam soon or I might not, but in any case, he won't be able to tell you much tonight. When Sam starts drinking, he becomes quite a rare character. If you can give me an envelope with a stamp and your address on it, I can find out where Sam might be tonight and mail it to you. But you'd better start looking for him early in the morning or you might not catch him, because Sam gets up early no matter how much he drank the night before.â€

BÃ¢y giá», tÃ´i chá»‰ cÃ³ thá»ƒ nÃ³i trÆ°á»›c Ä‘Æ°á»£c Ä‘iá»u nÃ y: tá»‘t nháº¥t lÃ  ngÃ i nÃªn Ä‘áº¿n gáº·p háº¯n vÃ o buá»•i sÃ¡ng sá»›m, náº¿u khÃ´ng thÃ¬ hÆ¡i khÃ³ Ä‘áº¥y, vÃ¬ háº¯n thÆ°á»ng dáº­y ráº¥t sá»›m vÃ  chá»‰ vá» Ä‘áº¿n nhÃ  vÃ o ná»­a Ä‘Ãªm, khi Ä‘Ã£ say khÆ°á»›t mÃ  thÃ´i.
vi_translation: â€” You see, I have no reason to keep you here. I can find this Sam guy right away, but maybe not. In any case, it won't be possible tonight. It's really hard to get anything out of this guy once he's had his fill of alcohol. If you leave me a stamped envelope with your address on it, I'll let you know as soon as I find out where he is. For now, I can only tell you this: it's best to meet him early in the morning, otherwise it will be quite difficult, because he usually wakes up very early and only comes home at midnight, completely drunk.

en: â€œNo, sir. But ye neednâ€™t have no difficulty about that. Itâ€™s a â€™igh â€™un with a stone front with a bow on it, anâ€™ â€™igh steps up to the door. I know them steps, â€™avinâ€™ â€™ad to carry the boxes up with three loafers what come round to earn a copper. The old gent give them shillinâ€™s, anâ€™ they seeinâ€™ they got so much, they wanted more; but â€™e took one of them by the shoulder and was like to throw â€™im down the steps, till the lot of them went away cussinâ€™.â€ I thought that with this description I could find the house, so, having paid my friend for his information, I started off for Piccadilly. I had gained a new painful experience; the Count could, it was evident, handle the earth-boxes himself. If so, time was precious; for, now that he had achieved a certain amount of distribution, he could, by choosing his own time, complete the task unobserved. At Piccadilly Circus I discharged my cab, and walked westward; beyond the Junior Constitutional I came across the house described, and was satisfied that this was the next of the lairs arranged by Dracula. The house looked as though it had been long untenanted. The windows were encrusted with dust, and the shutters were up. All the framework was black with time, and from the iron the paint had mostly scaled away. It was evident that up to lately there had been a large notice-board in front of the balcony; it had, however, been roughly torn away, the uprights which had supported it still remaining. Behind the rails of the balcony I saw there were some loose boards, whose raw edges looked white. I would have given a good deal to have been able to see the notice-board intact, as it would, perhaps, have given some clue to the ownership of the house. I remembered my experience of the investigation and purchase of Carfax, and I could not but feel that if I could find the former owner there might be some means discovered of gaining access to the house.
es: â€“No, seÃ±or. Pero no tendrÃ¡ dificultades en encontrarla. Es un edificio alto, con una fachada de piedra y un escudo de armas y unas escaleras bastante altas que llegan hasta la puerta de entrada. Recuerdo esas escaleras debido a que tuve que subir por ellas con las cajas, junto con tres muchachos que se acercaron para ganarse unos peniques. El viejo les dio chelines y, como vieron que les habÃ­a dado mucho, quisieron mÃ¡s todavÃ­a, pero el anciano agarrÃ³ a uno de ellos por el hombro y poco faltÃ³ para que lo echara por las escaleras; entonces, todos ellos se fueron, insultÃ¡ndolo. Pensaba que con esos informes no tendrÃ­a dificultades en encontrar la casa, de modo que despuÃ©s de pagarle a mi informante, me dirigÃ­ hacia Piccadilly. HabÃ­a adquirido una nueva y dolorosa experiencia. El conde podÃ­a por lo visto manejar las cajas solo. De ser asÃ­, el tiempo resultaba precioso, puesto que ya que habÃ­a llevado a cabo ciertas distribuciones, podrÃ­a llevar a cabo el resto de su trabajo, escogiendo el tiempo oportuno para ello, pasando completamente inadvertido. En Piccadilly Circus me apeÃ© y me dirigÃ­ caminando hacia el oeste; despuÃ©s de pasar el junior Constitutional, lleguÃ© ante la casa que me habÃ­a sido descrita y me satisfizo la idea de que se trataba del siguiente refugio que habÃ­a escogido DrÃ¡cula. La casa parecÃ­a haber estado desocupada durante mucho tiempo. Las ventanas estaban llenas de polvo y las persianas estaban levantadas. Toda la estructura estaba ennegrecida por el tiempo, y de las partes metÃ¡licas la pintura habÃ­a desaparecido. Era evidente que en el balcÃ³n superior habÃ­a habido un anuncio durante cierto tiempo, que habÃ­a sido retirado bruscamente, de tal modo que todavÃ­a quedaban los soportes verticales. DetrÃ¡s de la barandilla del balcÃ³n vi que sobresalÃ­an varias tablas sueltas, cuyos bordes parecÃ­an blancos. Hubiera dado mucho por poder ver intacto el anuncio, puesto que quizÃ¡ me hubiera dado alguna indicaciÃ³n en cuanto a la identidad de su propietario. Recordaba mi experiencia sobre la investigaciÃ³n y la compra de la casa de Carfax y no podÃ­a dejar de pensar que si podÃ­a encontrar al antiguo propietario era posible que descubriera algÃºn medio para entrar en la casa.
es_translation: â€“No, sir. But you will have no difficulty finding it. It is a tall building, with a stone facade and a coat of arms, and quite high stairs that lead up to the entrance door. I remember those stairs because I had to climb them with the boxes, along with three boys who came over to earn a few pennies. The old man gave them shillings and, seeing that he had given them a lot, they wanted even more, but the old man grabbed one of them by the shoulder and almost threw him down the stairs; then, they all left, insulting him. I thought that with those reports I would have no trouble finding the house, so after paying my informant, I headed towards Piccadilly. I had acquired a new and painful experience. The count could apparently handle the boxes alone. If so, time was precious, since having carried out certain distributions, he could carry out the rest of his work, choosing the opportune time for it, going completely unnoticed. At Piccadilly Circus I got off and walked west; after passing the Junior Constitutional, I arrived at the house that had been described to me and was satisfied with the idea that this was the next refuge Dracula had chosen. The house seemed to have been unoccupied for a long time. The windows were full of dust and the shutters were raised. The entire structure was blackened by time, and the paint had disappeared from the metal parts. It was evident that there had been an advertisement on the upper balcony for some time, which had been abruptly removed, so that the vertical supports still remained. Behind the balcony railing, I saw several loose boards protruding, whose edges appeared white. I would have given much to see the advertisement intact, as it might have given me some indication as to the identity of its owner. I remembered my experience investigating and purchasing the Carfax house and couldn't help but think that if I could find the former owner, I might discover some means of entering the house.

tr_translation: â€œNo, sir. But you won't have any trouble finding it. It's a tall building with an arched entrance and high steps leading to the door. I know those steps because I carried crates up them with three idlers who came to earn a few pence. The old man gave them each a shilling, and when they saw how much they got, they wanted more; but the man grabbed one of them by the shoulder and almost threw him down the stairs until they cursed and ran away.â€ I thought I could find the house with this description, so I paid my friend for the information and set off for Piccadilly. I had learned a new, painful fact: Apparently, the Count could carry the earth boxes by himself. If so, time was very precious, because now that he had ensured a certain number of distributions, he could complete the task unnoticed by choosing his own timing. I got out of the cab at Piccadilly Circus and walked west; behind the Junior Constitutional, I came across the described house and was convinced that this was the next refuge arranged by Dracula. The house looked like it hadn't been lived in for a long time. The windows were covered in dust, and the shutters were open. All the frames had darkened over time, and most of the paint on the iron had peeled off. It was clear that there had been a large signboard in front of the balcony until recently, but it had been roughly removed, with the posts that held it still standing there. Behind the balcony railings, I saw some loose boards with unpolished white edges. I would have given a lot to see the signboard in its entirety, as it would probably have given some clues about the owner of the house. I recalled my experiences with the investigation and sale of Carfax and couldn't help but think that if I could find the previous owner, there might be a way to enter the house.

vi_translation: â€” No, sir, but it should be easy to find! The house is tall, with a stone facade, low windows, and steps outside. I remember these steps because I had to carry the boxes up with three country lads who offered to help me in hopes of earning a few coins. The old man gave them a few shillings. Seeing an opportunity, they tried to ask for more, but the old man wouldn't have it. They were almost kicked down the stairs by the old man if they hadn't run away in time, cursing as they went. Thinking like that was enough to find the house, so I paid Bloxam and made my way to Piccadilly. What I had just learned left me bewildered: the count could lift the wooden crates filled with earth by himself! Every minute passing now was very precious to me. Because it was very likely that he had already scattered the crates, one in each place, at the time he had chosen beforehand so that no one would notice. Upon reaching Piccadilly Circus, I got off the carriage and headed straight towards the west of the neighborhood. Just past the Juvenile Court, I immediately recognized the house I was looking for. I had no doubt that it was one of Count Dracula's lairs in England. The house seemed to have been abandoned for a very long time. The arched windows were all open, but every window was covered in a layer of dust. The dust of time had turned the wooden panels black and the iron decorations into objects that looked like they were made of earth. Looking at the balcony wall, I guessed there must have been a sign with the address and house name that had just been torn off, as the traces were still very fresh. I would have more information if that sign were still intact: it would tell me the name of the house's owner. I still remember how I gathered information to secure the brokerage contract for the Carfax house for Dracula before, and now I also believe that if I knew the previous owner of the house, I would be able to get inside.

en: I found all the others at home. Mina was looking tired and pale, but she made a gallant effort to be bright and cheerful, it wrung my heart to think that I had had to keep anything from her and so caused her inquietude. Thank God, this will be the last night of her looking on at our conferences, and feeling the sting of our not showing our confidence. It took all my courage to hold to the wise resolution of keeping her out of our grim task. She seems somehow more reconciled; or else the very subject seems to have become repugnant to her, for when any accidental allusion is made she actually shudders. I am glad we made our resolution in time, as with such a feeling as this, our growing knowledge would be torture to her.
es: EncontrÃ© a todos los otros en la casa. Mina tenÃ­a aspecto pÃ¡lido y cansado, pero hizo un valeroso esfuerzo para parecer amable y animosa: me dolÃ­a pensar que habÃ­a tenido que ocultarle algo y que de ese modo la habÃ­a inquietado. Gracias a Dios, serÃ­a la Ãºltima noche que tendrÃ­a que estar cerca sin asistir a nuestras conferencias, creyendo en cierto modo que no era merecedora de nuestra confianza. NecesitÃ© todo mi valor para mantenerla realmente alejada de todo lo relativo a nuestro horrible trabajo. Parece estar en cierto modo mÃ¡s hecha a la idea, o el sujeto se le ha hecho repugnante, puesto que cada vez que se hace alguna alusiÃ³n accidental a ese tema, se estremece verdaderamente. Me alegro de que hayamos tomado nuestra resoluciÃ³n a tiempo, puesto que con sentimientos semejantes, nuestros conocimientos cada vez mayores serÃ­an una verdadera tortura para ella.
es_translation: I found all the others in the house. Mina looked pale and tired, but she made a valiant effort to appear kind and cheerful: it hurt me to think that I had to hide something from her and that it had thus worried her. Thank God, it would be the last night she would have to be nearby without attending our meetings, believing in some way that she was not worthy of our trust. I needed all my courage to keep her truly away from everything related to our horrible work. She seems to be somewhat more accustomed to the idea, or the subject has become repugnant to her, since every time there is an accidental allusion to that topic, she truly shudders. I'm glad we made our decision in time, because with such feelings, our ever-growing knowledge would be a true torture for her.

tr_translation: When I returned, I found everyone at home. Mina looked tired and pale, but she was making a brave effort to appear lively and cheerful; the thought that I had to hide something from her and thus caused her unease wrenched my heart. Thank God, this will be the last night she will have to witness our meetings and feel the pain of our lack of trust in her. I had mustered all my courage to maintain our wise decision to keep her out of our relentless task. Somehow, she now seems more at peace or perhaps the subject itself has become repulsive to her, because whenever it is accidentally mentioned, she genuinely shudders. I am glad we made our decision in time because the increasing knowledge coupled with such a feeling would have been torture for her.

vi_translation: When I got home, I saw everyone sitting in the living room. Mina still looked pale and even seemed more tired than in the morning, although she tried to appear cheerful with everyone. I felt a sharp pain in my heart thinking about how I had to grit my teeth and hide so many things from her, which only made her worry even more. Thank God! This would be the last night she would sit with us, feeling like no one trusted her anymore. As for myself, I had to make a great effort to come to a fair and reasonable decision regarding her. Mina seemed to completely accept my advice. Or is it that our adventure is now truly frightening her? Fortunately, we made a timely decision; otherwise, our new discoveries would be nothing short of torture for her, day and night.

en: Just a line. Mina sleeps soundly and her breathing is regular. Her forehead is puckered up into little wrinkles, as though she thinks even in her sleep. She is still too pale, but does not look so haggard as she did this morning. To-morrow will, I hope, mend all this; she will be herself at home in Exeter. Oh, but I am sleepy!

es_translation: Just one more line. Mina sleeps deeply and her breathing is regular. Her forehead is furrowed with small wrinkles, as if she were thinking even in her sleep. She is still very pale, but not as gaunt as this morning. Tomorrow I hope we can put an end to all this; she will go to our house in Exeter. Oh! How sleepy I am!

Her color is still very pale, but she doesn't look as exhausted as she did this morning. I hope tomorrow will set everything right; she will recover at home in Exeter. Oh, but I am very sleepy!

vi_translation: However, there are still a few lines I cannot help but write down. Mina is sleeping very soundly with steady breaths. I suddenly feel a deep sorrow when I notice the wrinkles on her graceful forehead. It seems that even in her sleep, worries and troubles do not leave her alone. Tomorrow, I hope everything will return to normal when she can come back to our home in Exeter. Oh! Why am I so sleepy!

en: â€œDr. Seward, you have been very considerate towards me. Believe me that I am very, very grateful to you!â€ I thought it well to leave him in this mood, and so I came away. There is certainly something to ponder over in this manâ€™s state. Several points seem to make what the American interviewer calls â€œa story,â€ if one could only get them in proper order. es: â€“Doctor Seward, ha sido usted muy considerado conmigo. Â¡CrÃ©ame que le estoy muy agradecido! CreÃ­ que serÃ­a conveniente dejarlo en ese momento y me fui. en: Later.â€”We have met again. We seem at last to be on the track, and our work of to-morrow may be the beginning of the end. I wonder if Renfieldâ€™s quiet has anything to do with this. His moods have so followed the doings of the Count, that the coming destruction of the monster may be carried to him in some subtle way. If we could only get some hint as to what passed in his mind, between the time of my argument with him to-day and his resumption of fly-catching, it might afford us a valuable clue. He is now seemingly quiet for a spell.... Is he?â€”â€” That wild yell seemed to come from his room....

es_translation: Later. We have gathered again. It seems that we are finally on the right track and that tomorrow's work may very well be the beginning of the end. I wonder if Renfield's calmness has anything to do with it. His mood swings have been so closely aligned with the count's movements that the imminent destruction of the monster may have been revealed to him in some subtle way. If we could have some idea of what is going on in his mind, especially between the moment I was talking to him and the moment he returned to his fly-catching, I could consider it a valuable clue. Apparently, he was going to be calm for a while... Could it be true...? That horrible scream seems to come from his room...

vi_translation: But no, nothing at all... not even a fly. When the moonlight appeared, I started to get insanely angry at him. When I saw him slithering into the room through the still-closed window, I truly lost my temper. Seeing me go mad, he laughed gleefully, his eyes shining like fire through a shroud of mist. I think that at that moment, Mrs. Harker had already returned to her room.

en: â€œAnd now, Madam Minaâ€”poor, dear, dear Madam Minaâ€”tell us exactly what happened. God knows that I do not want that you be pained; but it is need that we know all. For now more than ever has all work to be done quick and sharp, and in deadly earnest. The day is close to us that must end all, if it may be so; and now is the chance that we may live and learn.â€

tr_translation: â€œAnd now Madam Mina -poor, dear, dear Madam Mina- tell us exactly what happened. God knows I don't want you to suffer, but it is necessary for us to know everything. Because now, we must conduct our work faster and more perfectly than ever before, and this is no joke. If it can be, the day that will end everything is approaching, and we now have the chance to live and learn.â€

vi_translation: â€” Mina, now can you tell us what happened? The Lord wants you to share this pain with us, but it is essential now that we know every detail related to you just now. More than ever, we need to act very quickly. We can reach the goal, but the opportunity will come faster if we know more about the situation to achieve the final victory.

en: â€œThen,â€ he looked at me as keenly as he spoke, â€œall that is in doubt is the conscience of the employer, and the belief of your policemen as to whether or no that employer has a good conscience or a bad one. Your police must indeed be zealous men and cleverâ€”oh, so clever!â€”in reading the heart, that they trouble themselves in such matter. No, no, my friend Jonathan, you go take the lock off a hundred empty house in this your London, or of any city in the world; and if you do it as such things are rightly done, and at the time such things are rightly done, no one will interfere. I have read of a gentleman who owned a so fine house in London, and when he went for months of summer to Switzerland and lock up his house, some burglar came and broke window at back and got in. Then he went and made open the shutters in front and walk out and in through the door, before the very eyes of the police. Then he have an auction in that house, and advertise it, and put up big notice; and when the day come he sell off by a great auctioneer all the goods of that other man who own them. Then he go to a builder, and he sell him that house, making an agreement that he pull it down and take all away within a certain time. And your police and other authority help him all they can. And when that owner come back from his holiday in Switzerland he find only an empty hole where his house had been. This was all done en rÃ¨gle; and in our work we shall be en rÃ¨gle too. We shall not go so early that the policemen who have then little to think of, shall deem it strange; but we shall go after ten oâ€™clock, when there are many about, and such things would be done were we indeed owners of the house.â€
es: â€“Entonces -me mirÃ³ fijamente, al tiempo que continuaba -, todo lo que estarÃ¡ en duda es la conciencia y la opiniÃ³n de la policÃ­a en cuanto a si es el propietario quien recurriÃ³ al cerrajero y la opiniÃ³n de la policÃ­a en cuanto a si el artesano estÃ¡ trabajando o no de acuerdo con las leyes. Su policÃ­a debe estar compuesta de hombres cuidadosos e inteligentes, extraordinariamente inteligentes para leer el corazÃ³n humano, si es que han de estar seguros de lo que deben hacer. No, no, amigo Jonathan, puede usted ir a abrir las cerraduras de un centenar de casas vacÃ­as en su Londres o en cualquier ciudad del mundo, y si lo hace de tal modo que parezca correcto, nadie intervendrÃ¡ en absoluto. He leÃ­do algo sobre un caballero que tenÃ­a una hermosa casa en Londres y cuando fue a pasar los meses del verano en Suiza, dejando su casa cerrada, un delincuente rompiÃ³ una de las ventanas de la parte posterior y entrÃ³. Luego se dirigiÃ³ al frente, abriÃ³ las ventanas, levantÃ³ las persianas y saliÃ³ por la puerta principal, ante los mismos ojos de la policÃ­a. A continuaciÃ³n, hizo una pÃºblica subasta en la casa, la anunciÃ³ en todos los periÃ³dicos y, cuando llegÃ³ el dÃ­a establecido, vendiÃ³ todas las posesiones del caballero que se encontraba fuera. Luego, fue a ver a un constructor y le vendiÃ³ la casa, estableciendo el acuerdo de que deberÃ­a derribarla y retirar todos los escombros antes de una fecha determinada. Tanto la policÃ­a como el resto de las autoridades inglesas lo ayudaron todo lo que pudieron. Cuando el verdadero propietario regresÃ³ de Suiza encontrÃ³ solamente un solar vacÃ­o en el lugar en que habÃ­a estado su casa. Ese delito fue llevado a cabo en rÃ©gle, y nuestro trabajo debe llevarse a cabo tambiÃ©n en rÃ©gle. No debemos ir tan temprano que los policÃ­as sospechen de nuestros actos; por el contrario, debemos ir despuÃ©s de las diez de la maÃ±ana, cuando haya muchos agentes en torno nuestro, y nos comportaremos como si fuÃ©ramos realmente los propietarios de la casa.
es_translation: â€“Then -he looked at me intently, while continuing -, all that will be in doubt is the conscience and opinion of the police as to whether it is the owner who called the locksmith and the opinion of the police as to whether the craftsman is working in accordance with the laws or not. Your police must be composed of careful and intelligent men, extraordinarily intelligent to read the human heart, if they are to be sure of what they should do. No, no, my friend Jonathan, you can go and open the locks of a hundred empty houses in your London or any city in the world, and if you do it in such a way that it seems correct, no one will intervene at all. I have read something about a gentleman who had a beautiful house in London and when he went to spend the summer months in Switzerland, leaving his house closed, a criminal broke one of the back windows and entered. Then he went to the front, opened the windows, raised the shutters, and walked out the front door, right in front of the police. Next, he held a public auction in the house, advertised it in all the newspapers, and when the appointed day came, he sold all the possessions of the gentleman who was away. Then, he went to see a builder and sold him the house, establishing the agreement that it should be demolished and all the debris removed before a certain date. Both the police and the rest of the English authorities helped him as much as they could. When the real owner returned from Switzerland, he found only an empty lot where his house had been. That crime was carried out in rÃ©gle, and our work must also be carried out in rÃ©gle. We must not go so early that the police suspect our actions; on the contrary, we must go after ten in the morning, when there are many officers around us, and we will behave as if we were really the owners of the house.

tr_translation: "Then," he said, looking at me with sharp eyes while speaking, "the only uncertain thing is the employer's conscience and your police officers' belief regarding whether that employer has a clean conscience or not. Your police officers, given that they trouble themselves with such a matter, must be willing and smart - oh, how smart - in reading the human heart. No, no, my friend Jonathan, even if you unlock a hundred empty houses in your London or any other city in the world and do the job as it should be done, no one will interfere with your work. I had read the story of a gentleman who had a very nice house in your London and went to Switzerland for a few months in the summer, closing up his house, only for a thief to break in through the back window. Then, the thief went and opened the shutters in the front and entered and exited through the door right in front of the police. After that, he held an auction in the house, announced it, placed a big advertisement, and on the day it came, sold everything the other man owned through a major auctioneer. Then he went to a contractor and sold the house to him, agreeing to demolish it and clear it all away within a certain period. And your police and other authorities provided him with all the help they could. And when that homeowner returned from his Swiss vacation, he found nothing but a big empty space where his house used to be. All of this was done en rÃ¨gle, and we will act en rÃ¨gle while doing our job. We won't go so early that the police, who don't have much to think about at those hours, will find the situation strange; we'll go after ten, at a time when there will be many people around and such things would be done by the real owners of the house."

vi_translation: Additionally, the success of the operation also depends on the gullibility of the local police officers. But my dear friend Jonathan, sometimes you can still use a hook to unlock hundreds of houses in London or anywhere else in the world without any trouble, as long as you create the right circumstances and do it at the right time. I can tell everyone a story that I once read. The story goes like this: There was a gentleman who owned a beautiful mansion in London. That summer, due to having to go to Switzerland for quite a long time, about five to seven months, he carelessly locked the house before leaving and didn't ask anyone to look after it. As a result, shortly after he left, a thief broke the glass of a window facing the garden and broke in. Once inside, he opened all the windows at the front of the house and boldly walked out the front door right in front of the police. After that, he openly advertised the sale of all the furniture in the house with a huge advertisement board posted on the wall outside the gate. He hired an auction representative to sell all the belongings of the gentleman who was in Switzerland. Then, he even sold the house itself to a building contractor because he found the ownership papers stored in the house. The contractor discussed with him to demolish the house on a specific day to build a new building. The police and city authorities thought he was the real owner of the mansion, so they facilitated this construction contract handover. Unfortunately for the real owner of the house, when he returned from Switzerland, all he saw was a giant hole in place of his familiar house. But what could be done, everything happened legally, following the city's buying and building regulations. Perhaps our work should also follow similar principles. We shouldn't arrive at Piccadilly too early to avoid the scrutiny of the police; only then will they not accidentally notice that our presence is unusual. At the earliest, we should only start from ten o'clock onwards, because by then, passersby will think we are the real owners of the house.

en: There was hope in his words, and comfort; and they made for resignation. Mina and I both felt so, and simultaneously we each took one of the old manâ€™s hands and bent over and kissed it. Then without a word we all knelt down together, and, all holding hands, swore to be true to each other. We men pledged ourselves to raise the veil of sorrow from the head of her whom, each in his own way, we loved; and we prayed for help and guidance in the terrible task which lay before us.
es: HabÃ­a esperanza en sus palabras y tambiÃ©n consuelo. AdemÃ¡s, nos invitaban a resignarnos. Mina y yo lo comprendimos asÃ­ y, simultÃ¡neamente, tomamos cada uno de nosotros una de las manos del anciano y se la besamos humildemente. Luego, sin pronunciar una sola palabra, todos nos arrodillamos juntos y, tomÃ¡ndonos de la mano, juramos ser sinceros unos con otros y pedimos ayuda y guÃ­a en la terrible tarea que nos esperaba. Todos los hombres nos esforzamos en retirar de Mina el velo de profunda tristeza que la cubrÃ­a, debido a que todos, cada quien a su manera, la amÃ¡bamos.
es_translation: There was hope in his words and also comfort. Moreover, they invited us to resign ourselves. Mina and I understood it that way and, simultaneously, each of us took one of the old man's hands and kissed it humbly. Then, without uttering a single word, we all knelt together and, holding hands, swore to be sincere with one another and asked for help and guidance in the terrible task that awaited us. All the men strove to lift from Mina the veil of deep sadness that enveloped her, because we all, each in our own way, loved her.

Biz erkekler, hepimizin kendimize gÃ¶re sevdiÄŸimiz Minaâ€™nÄ±n yÃ¼zÃ¼nÃ¼ Ã¶rten acÄ± perdesini kaldÄ±rmaya ant iÃ§tik ve Ã¶nÃ¼mÃ¼zdeki korkunÃ§ gÃ¶revde bize yardÄ±m edip yol gÃ¶stermesi iÃ§in TanrÄ±â€™ya dua ettik.
tr_translation: There was hope and solace in his words, and it led to resignation. Mina and I felt this way, and at the same time, we both held one of the old man's hands, leaned over, and kissed it. Then, without saying a word, we all knelt together, holding hands, and vowed to remain faithful to each other. We men swore to lift the veil of sorrow covering the face of Mina, whom we all loved in our own way, and prayed to God to help and guide us in the dreadful task ahead.

VÃ  trÆ°á»›c ChÃºa linh thiÃªng, cáº£ nhÃ³m chÃºng tÃ´i, khÃ´ng ai báº£o ai, cÃ¹ng quá»³ xuá»‘ng thá» sá»‘ng cháº¿t cÃ³ nhau, Ä‘á»“ng sá»©c Ä‘á»“ng lÃ²ng vá»›i nhau, cÃ¹ng nhau cáº§u ChÃºa phÃ¹ há»™ cho chÃºng tÃ´i qua khá»i cÆ¡n hoáº¡n náº¡n Ä‘á»ƒ hoÃ n thÃ nh sá»© má»‡nh cá»§a mÃ¬nh.
vi_translation: The sincere encouragement from the professor helped us understand that we need to endure when we must endure, and it seemed that behind that endurance, there was still a little something for us to hope for. Mina and I both felt it, we were truly moved, each of us bowed down, took one of his hands, and placed a kiss on it as a gesture of gratitude towards the heart of an old father. And before the sacred Lord, our whole group, without anyone telling anyone, knelt down together and swore to live and die together, united in strength and spirit, praying together for the Lord to help us overcome the calamity to complete our mission.

en: Whilst he was speaking we were startled by a knock at the hall door, the double postmanâ€™s knock of the telegraph boy. We all moved out to the hall with one impulse, and Van Helsing, holding up his hand to us to keep silence, stepped to the door and opened it. The boy handed in a despatch. The Professor closed the door again, and, after looking at the direction, opened it and read aloud.
es: Mientras hablÃ¡bamos, nos sorprendimos mucho al escuchar una llamada en la puerta principal de la casona: la doble llamada del repartidor de mensajes telegrÃ¡ficos. Todos salimos al vestÃ­bulo al mismo tiempo, y van Helsing, levantando la mano hacia nosotros para que guardÃ¡ramos silencio, se dirigiÃ³ hacia la puerta y la abriÃ³. Un joven le tendiÃ³ un telegrama.
es_translation: While we were talking, we were very surprised to hear a call at the main door of the mansion: the double call of the telegraph message delivery person. We all went out into the lobby at the same time, and Van Helsing, raising his hand towards us to keep silent, walked towards the door and opened it. A young man handed him a telegram. The professor closed the door again and, after examining the address, opened it and read aloud: "Beware of D.

With a single impulse, we all went out into the hall, and Van Helsing, raising his hand to signal us to be silent, went to the door and opened it. The boy handed over the delivery. The professor closed the door again, and after looking at the address, he opened the telegram and read it aloud:

vi_translation: Van Helsing had not finished speaking when a sudden, rough knock on the door startled everyone. We anxiously stepped out into the hallway. The professor signaled for everyone to remain silent and went to open the door by himself. It turned out to be a postal worker! He handed the professor a telegram. After glancing at the address on the telegram, the professor quickly slammed the door shut as soon as the postal worker left.

es_translation: â€“We have no choice but to wait here. However, if he does not arrive before five in the afternoon, we will have to leave, since we cannot leave Mrs. Harker alone after sunset.

vi_translation: â€” There's nothing left to do but sit and wait here. But if we wait until five o'clock and he still hasn't arrived, we might have to go back. We can't leave Mina at home alone after sunset. â€” He must be about to show up soon.

en: 3-4 October, close to midnight.â€”I thought yesterday would never end. There was over me a yearning for sleep, in some sort of blind belief that to wake would be to find things changed, and that any change must now be for the better. Before we parted, we discussed what our next step was to be, but we could arrive at no result. All we knew was that one earth-box remained, and that the Count alone knew where it was. If he chooses to lie hidden, he may baffle us for years; and in the meantime!â€”the thought is too horrible, I dare not think of it even now. This I know: that if ever there was a woman who was all perfection, that one is my poor wronged darling. I love her a thousand times more for her sweet pity of last night, a pity that made my own hate of the monster seem despicable. Surely God will not permit the world to be the poorer by the loss of such a creature. This is hope to me. We are all drifting reefwards now, and faith is our only anchor. Thank God! Mina is sleeping, and sleeping without dreams. I fear what her dreams might be like, with such terrible memories to ground them in. She has not been so calm, within my seeing, since the sunset. Then, for a while, there came over her face a repose which was like spring after the blasts of March. I thought at the time that it was the softness of the red sunset on her face, but somehow now I think it has a deeper meaning. I am not sleepy myself, though I am wearyâ€”weary to death. However, I must try to sleep; for there is to-morrow to think of, and there is no rest for me until....

es_translation: October 3-4, near midnight. I thought yesterday would never end. I had the desire to fall asleep, hoping that upon waking I would discover that things had changed and that all changes would henceforth be for the better. Before we parted ways, we discussed what our next step should be, but we couldn't reach any conclusion. The only thing we knew was that there was still one box of earth left and that only the count knew where it was. If he wishes to remain hidden, he can confuse us for years on end and, in the meantime, the thought is too horrible; I cannot allow myself to think about it at this moment. What I do know is that if there has ever been an absolutely perfect woman, it is my beloved and wounded wife. I love her a thousand times more for her sweet compassion last night; a compassion that made even the hatred I have for the monster seem despicable. I am sure that God will not allow the world to be impoverished by the loss of such a creature. That is a hope for me. We are all heading towards the rocks, and hope is the only anchor I have left. Thank God, Mina is asleep and not having nightmares. I dread to think what her nightmares could be, with such terrible memories that could provoke them. She hasn't been this calm, as far as I could see, since sunset. Then, for a moment, a calm spread over her face, like spring after the storms of March. I thought at that moment that it must be the reflection of the sunset on her face, but, in some way, I now know that it was something much deeper. I am not sleepy myself, although I am tired... Terribly tired. However, I must try to fall asleep, as I have to think about tomorrow, and that there will be no rest for me until...

tr_translation: 3-4 October, near midnight. - I thought yesterday would never end. I fell asleep with a blind belief that everything would be different when I woke up and that any change would now be for the better. Before parting, we discussed what our next step would be, but we couldn't reach a conclusion. All we knew was that there was one more of the earth boxes and only the Count knew where it was. If he chose to hide, he could keep us at bay for years, and in the meantime... The thought is so terrifying that I dare not even think of it now. This I know: If there is a perfectly virtuous woman, it is my poor, wronged beloved. Because of the sweet pity I felt last nightâ€”a pity so profound that it made even my hatred for the monster seem baseâ€”I love her a thousand times more. God will surely not allow the world to become more wretched by losing such a creature. This is my hope. Now we are all caught in the current, heading towards the shallow rocks, and faith is our only assurance. Thank God! Mina is sleeping and not dreaming. I fear what her dreams might be like, based on such terrible memories. From what I can see, she hasn't been very calm since sunset. Then, for a while, a peace settled on her face, like the calm that follows the sudden winds of March. At the time, I thought it was the softness of the red sunset falling on her face, but now I think it has a deeper meaning somehow. Despite being very exhaustedâ€”dead tiredâ€”I am not sleepy. But I must try to sleep because there is a tomorrow I need to think about, and there is no peace for me until then...

vi_translation: â€¢ October 3 - 4, after midnight It seemed like yesterday would never end. There was something urging me to fall asleep, a vague belief telling me that when I woke up, I would witness a change and from now on, everything would change favorably for us. Before wishing each other good night, we had a discussion about the next step but did not come to any conclusion. All we knew was: there was still a wooden crate where the old count could hide, and only he knew where it was hidden. If he chose to remain in hiding, he would force us to fail for many years, but what we needed right now... The prospect before us was truly terrifying, making me afraid to make any guesses. I am not sure about one thing, that is if there ever was a perfect woman, but with a tragic fate, it would be my beloved wife. The more I thought, the more I loved her to the point of heartache and the more I hated that demon a thousand times over. Surely God would not let this world be impoverished by the loss of a creation like her. So within me surged a hope of certain victory. Now we are lost and have only one anchor left, which is faith. Thank God, Mina slept without any troubling dreams. I am very afraid of what might be in her dreams stemming from her terrifying memories. Since dusk until now, I have not seen her show any signs of pain or distress. In a moment, I recognized the peace on her face, like the spring weather after the sudden rains of March... I did not feel sleepy, even though I felt utterly exhausted. However, I forced myself to sleep, needing to think about tomorrow. I will not be at ease until...

en: Later.â€”I must have fallen asleep, for I was awaked by Mina, who was sitting up in bed, with a startled look on her face. I could see easily, for we did not leave the room in darkness; she had placed a warning hand over my mouth, and now she whispered in my ear:â€”

vi_translation: His gestures and gaze forced me to remain silent, and I could only turn around and whisper his words to Mina. She sighed in relief, wrapped her arms tightly around me, and said affectionately:

en: â€œI have an idea. I suppose it must have come in the night, and matured without my knowing it. He must hypnotise me before the dawn, and then I shall be able to speak. Go quick, dearest; the time is getting close.â€ I went to the door. Dr. Seward was resting on the mattress, and, seeing me, he sprang to his feet.

en: 5 October, afternoon.â€”For some time after our meeting this morning I could not think. The new phases of things leave my mind in a state of wonder which allows no room for active thought. The way the others received it, too, puzzled me; the last time we talked of the subject we agreed that there was to be no more concealment of anything amongst us. Mina is sleeping now, calmly and sweetly like a little child. Her lips are curved and her face beams with happiness. Thank God, there are such moments still for her.

es_translation: October, in the afternoon. For a good while, after our meeting this morning, I couldn't reflect. The new phases of the matters left my mind in such a state that it was impossible for me to think clearly. Mina's determination not to take an active part in the discussion had me worried, and since I couldn't discuss it with her, I could only try to guess. I am still as far as ever from having found the solution to that enigma. Moreover, the way the others received that determination astonished me; the last time we talked about all this, we agreed that we should no longer hide anything at all from each other. Mina is asleep now, calm and peaceful like a little girl. Her lips are slightly parted and her face smiles with happiness. Thank God, even she can still enjoy such moments!

tr_translation: October 5, afternoon. - After our meeting this morning, I couldn't think for a while. The new stages the work had reached had piqued my curiosity in such a way that there was no room left in my mind for active thoughts. Mina's determination not to participate in the meeting had made me ponder, and since I couldn't discuss this with her, I could only speculate. At this moment, I am further from reaching a conclusion than ever before. Mina is now sleeping beautifully and sweetly like a child. Her lips are curved, and her face is glowing with happiness. Thank God, she can still have such moments.

vi_translation: â€¢ October 5, afternoon After this morning's group meeting, I suddenly felt an unusual emptiness in my mind. The new developments have put me in a state where I can no longer think of anything positive. The decision not to let Mina participate in the group discussions made me ponder a lot. Mina is sleeping, her face peaceful, carefree, and innocent like a child, her face radiating happiness. Thank God! At least she still gets to enjoy such moments of peace.

They were all so tired, discouraged, and sad that it was impossible to do anything without them resting first; therefore, I asked everyone to lie down for half an hour while I wrote everything down, updating the diaries to the current moment. I feel very grateful to the inventor of the portable typewriter and to Mr. Morris, who got this one for me. The work would have been a bit tedious if I had had to write everything with a pen...
