vi_translation: â€¢ October 30, in the afternoon They look so tired and discouraged! At this rate, no one will be able to do anything without taking a little rest. Therefore, I had to urge them to lie down for about half an hour, during which time I will record everything that has happened so far. I am truly grateful to whoever invented the portable typewriter and to Quincey Morris, who took the trouble to bring it here for me! Surely, I would lose my train of thought if I had to keep sharpening my pen on the paper...

en: It is all done; poor dear, dear Jonathan, what he must have suffered, what must he be suffering now. He lies on the sofa hardly seeming to breathe, and his whole body appears in collapse. His brows are knit; his face is drawn with pain. Poor fellow, maybe he is thinking, and I can see his face all wrinkled up with the concentration of his thoughts. Oh! if I could only help at all.... I shall do what I can.

es_translation: Everything is done; poor and dear Jonathan, how much he has suffered and how much he must still be suffering! He is lying on the divan and it is barely noticeable that he is breathing; his entire body seems to be a victim of a collapse. He has a furrowed brow and his face clearly reflects his suffering. Poor man, perhaps he is thinking and I can see his wrinkled face, due to his reflections. If only I could be of some use to themâ€¦! I will do everything possible.

vi_translation: At my suggestion, Dr. Van Helsing handed over to me all the records that I had not yet seen. While he is on vacation, I plan to thoroughly read through everything and, if possible, draw some conclusions. I strive to follow the professor's example and think objectively about the events laid out before me.

en: The box was given to Skinsky before sunrise. At sunrise the Count could appear in his own form. Here, we ask why Skinsky was chosen at all to aid in the work? In my husbandâ€™s diary, Skinsky is mentioned as dealing with the Slovaks who trade down the river to the port; and the manâ€™s remark, that the murder was the work of a Slovak, showed the general feeling against his class. The Count wanted isolation.

es_translation: The box was delivered to Skinsky before sunrise. At sunrise, the count could appear in his true form. Here we ask: why was Skinsky chosen to carry out this task? In my husband's diary, the said Skinsky is indicated as an individual who trafficked with the Slovaks who traded by the river, up to the port; and the cry of the women, that the crime had been committed by Slovaks, showed the general sentiment against those of his kind. The count desired isolation.

vi_translation: The wooden box was handed over to Skinsky before dawn. At sunrise, the old count could appear in his true form. We need to understand why Skinsky was chosen as an accomplice. According to my husband's diary, Skinsky has connections with the Slovaki people who are trading upstream at the port. And the rumored murderer is said to be a Slovaki; this notable detail indicates that people often think of these individuals. Did the old count intend to divert everyone's attention?

en: â€œOur dear Madam Mina is once more our teacher. Her eyes have been where we were blinded. Now we are on the track once again, and this time we may succeed. Our enemy is at his most helpless; and if we can come on him by day, on the water, our task will be over. He has a start, but he is powerless to hasten, as he may not leave his box lest those who carry him may suspect; for them to suspect would be to prompt them to throw him in the stream where he perish. This he knows, and will not. Now men, to our Council of War; for, here and now, we must plan what each and all shall do.â€
es: â€“Nuestra querida seÃ±ora Mina es, una vez mÃ¡s, nuestra maestra. Sus ojos se han posado en donde nosotros no habÃ­amos visto nada. Tiene cierta ventaja, pero no puede apresurarse, ya que no puede abandonar su caja con el fin de no despertar sospechas entre quienes lo transportan; en el caso de que ellos sospecharan algo, su primera reacciÃ³n serÃ­a la de arrojarlo inmediatamente por la borda, y perecerÃ­a en el agua. es_translation: â€“Our dear lady Mina is, once again, our teacher. Her eyes have settled where we had seen nothing. Now, we are back on track and, this time, we can triumph. Our enemy is at his weakest point and, if we can reach him during the day, over the water, our task will be concluded. He has some advantage, but he cannot hurry, as he cannot leave his box in order not to arouse suspicion among those who transport him; if they suspected anything, their first reaction would be to immediately throw him overboard, and he would perish in the water. Naturally, he knows that and cannot expose himself. Now, friends, let us hold our war council, since it is necessary that we plan right here, at this very moment, what each of us must do.

tr_translation: â€œDear Madam Mina has once again become our teacher. Where we were blind, her eyes saw. Now we are once again on the trail, and this time we may succeed. Our enemy is at his weakest, and if we can find him in the water during the day, our task will be over. He started a step ahead, but because he cannot leave his box without arousing suspicion from those carrying him, he is too weak to hasten; to arouse suspicion in his men would mean provoking them to cast him into the stream where he would be lost forever. He knows this and will not do so. Now, gentlemen, let us convene our war council, for we must plan what each of us is to do.â€

vi_translation: â€” Once again, Mina proves herself worthy of being the guide of our group. She is truly perceptive, while we are just blind men. We have found the trail again, and if we encounter the enemy in broad daylight, on the water, our mission will be considered accomplished. Indeed, he is ahead of us, but he cannot move quickly; how could he dare to leave that coffin? The people escorting the box will surely become suspicious, and at the first sign of anything unusual, they would be ready to throw that cursed thing into the river. He understands this well and certainly wouldn't dare to do anything foolish. Now, we need to confer a bit because we must discuss the tasks each of us needs to undertake. â€” I will go look for a boat and the accompanying accessories.

en: â€œGood!â€ said the Professor, â€œboth good. But neither must go alone. There must be force to overcome force if need be; the Slovak is strong and rough, and he carries rude arms.â€ All the men smiled, for amongst them they carried a small arsenal. Said Mr. Morris:â€”

vi_translation: â€” Good. - The professor continued. - Both of you have valid points, but you shouldn't go alone. You need to have strength if you encounter strength. The Slovakians are very strong and aggressive, and they are often fully armed. Everyone burst out laughing, as each person was ready to carry a small box of bullets. â€” I have brought along a few guns. - Morris said. -

en: 31 October.â€”Arrived at Veresti at noon. The Professor tells me that this morning at dawn he could hardly hypnotise me at all, and that all I could say was: â€œdark and quiet.â€ He is off now buying a carriage and horses. He says that he will later on try to buy additional horses, so that we may be able to change them on the way. We have something more than 70 miles before us. The country is lovely, and most interesting; if only we were under different conditions, how delightful it would be to see it all. If Jonathan and I were driving through it alone what a pleasure it would be. To stop and see people, and learn something of their life, and to fill our minds and memories with all the colour and picturesqueness of the whole wild, beautiful country and the quaint people! But, alas!â€”
es: 31 de octubre. Llegamos a Veresti por la tarde. El profesor me dice que esta maÃ±ana, al amanecer, a duras penas pudo hipnotizarme, y que todo lo que pude decir fue: "oscuro y tranquilo". El paisaje es precioso y muy interesante; si nos encontrÃ¡ramos en diferentes circunstancias, Â¡quÃ© encantador resultarÃ­a contemplar todo esto! Si Jonathan y yo viajÃ¡ramos solos por estas tierras, Â¡quÃ© placer serÃ­a! PodrÃ­amos detenernos, verÃ­amos a la gente, aprenderÃ­amos algo sobre ella y llenarÃ­amos nuestras mentes con todo lo pintoresco y el colorido del campo salvaje y hermoso y las personas tan singulares. Pero, Â¡ayâ€¦!
es_translation: October 31. We arrived in Veresti in the afternoon. The professor tells me that this morning, at dawn, he could barely hypnotize me, and all I could say was: "dark and quiet". He is now out, buying a carriage and horses; he says that later he will try to buy more horses, so that we can change them along the way. We still have one hundred and ten kilometers to go. The landscape is beautiful and very interesting; if we were in different circumstances, how delightful it would be to contemplate all this! If Jonathan and I were traveling alone through these lands, what a pleasure it would be! We could stop, see the people, learn something about them, and fill our minds with all the picturesque and colorful aspects of the wild and beautiful countryside and the unique people. But, alasâ€¦!

tr_translation: October 31. - We arrived in Veresti at noon. The Professor said that he had great difficulty hypnotizing me at dawn this morning and that all I could say was, "dark and silent." Now he is outside to get a carriage and horses. He says he will also try to get spare horses so that we can change them on the road later. We have more than a hundred kilometers ahead of us. The region is very beautiful and very interesting; how delightful it would have been to see all this if we had come under different circumstances. What a great pleasure it would have been if Jonathan and I were passing through here alone. Stopping to see the people, learning something about their lives, filling our minds and memories with all the colors and impressiveness of these wild, beautiful lands and interesting people! But alas!

vi_translation: We arrived in Veresti at noon. The professor told me that at dawn today, he had a hard time hypnotizing me, and even then, I couldn't say anything else: "Pitch dark, quiet". He went to buy a carriage and a few horses for reinforcement - if possible - to alternate pulling on the road. The road we traveled was endlessly long. This land is truly beautiful and full of interesting things. If only we were traveling under this sky in different circumstances, how wonderful it would be! If only Jonathan and I could walk together on this road, how romantic it would be! Oh, those unfamiliar people, those magical and wild sceneries!... â€¢ A moment later

en: Later.â€”Dr. Van Helsing has returned. He has got the carriage and horses; we are to have some dinner, and to start in an hour. The landlady is putting us up a huge basket of provisions; it seems enough for a company of soldiers. The Professor encourages her, and whispers to me that it may be a week before we can get any good food again. He has been shopping too, and has sent home such a wonderful lot of fur coats and wraps, and all sorts of warm things. There will not be any chance of our being cold.
es: MÃ¡s tarde. El doctor van Helsing ha regresado. ConsiguiÃ³ la calesa y los caballos; vamos a cenar, y emprenderemos el viaje dentro de una hora. La casera nos estÃ¡ preparando una enorme canasta de provisiones; parece ser suficiente para toda una compaÃ±Ã­a de soldados. El profesor la anima y me dice en susurros que es posible que pase una semana antes de que podamos volver a obtener alimentos. El tambiÃ©n ha estado de compras, y ha enviado a su casa un conjunto maravilloso de abrigos y pellizas y toda clase de ropa de abrigo. No tendremos ningÃºn peligro de sentir frÃ­o.
es_translation: Later. Dr. Van Helsing has returned. He got the carriage and the horses; we are going to have dinner, and we will set off within an hour. The landlady is preparing a huge basket of provisions for us; it seems to be enough for an entire company of soldiers. The professor encourages her and whispers to me that it might be a week before we can get more food. He has also been shopping, and has sent a wonderful set of coats and furs and all kinds of warm clothing to his house. We will have no danger of feeling cold.

Our hostess prepared a huge basket full of provisions for us; it looks like enough to feed an army. The professor supports the woman and whispers to me that we might not find food for maybe a week. He also went shopping and sent home a lot of excellent coats and blankets and all kinds of materials to keep warm. There will be no chance of us getting cold.

vi_translation: Dr. Van Helsing returned with a carriage and a few horses. Additionally, he bought a lot of woolen blankets and a few fur coats to prepare for the bone-chilling cold. We had to eat well and then depart in an hour. But the innkeeper brought out a basket of mixed food like what is usually given to soldiers. The professor had to whisper in my ear that in a week, we might not find any other pleasant food, so we had to make an effort to eat. In a little while, we will be on our way.

en: We shall soon be off. I am afraid to think what may happen to us. We are truly in the hands of God. He alone knows what may be, and I pray Him, with all the strength of my sad and humble soul, that He will watch over my beloved husband; that whatever may happen, Jonathan may know that I loved him and honoured him more than I can say, and that my latest and truest thought will be always for him.
es: Pronto nos pondremos en marcha. Temo pensar en lo que puede sucedernos; verdaderamente, estamos en las manos de Dios; solamente Ã‰l sabe lo que puede suceder y le ruego, con toda la fuerza de mi alma triste y humilde, que cuide a mi amado esposo; que, suceda lo que suceda, Jonathan pueda saber que lo amo y que lo he honrado mÃ¡s de lo que puedo expresar, y que mi Ãºltimo y mÃ¡s sincero pensamiento afectuoso serÃ¡ siempre para Ã©l.
es_translation: Soon we will set out. I dread to think of what may happen to us; truly, we are in God's hands; only He knows what may happen and I pray to Him, with all the strength of my sad and humble soul, to take care of my beloved husband; that, whatever happens, Jonathan may know that I love him and that I have honored him more than I can express, and that my last and most sincere affectionate thought will always be for him.

vi_translation: In a little while, we will be on our way. My body suddenly trembled when I thought of what awaits us along the journey. But honestly, I still believe in God's protection. Only He knows what will happen, but no matter what, I pray that my beloved husband will return safely. I wish Jonathan could understand the sincere feelings I have always had for him from the bottom of my heart!

en: 2 November, morning.â€”I was successful, and we took turns driving all night; now the day is on us, bright though cold. There is a strange heaviness in the airâ€”I say heaviness for want of a better word; I mean that it oppresses us both. It is very cold, and only our warm furs keep us comfortable. At dawn Van Helsing hypnotised me; he says I answered â€œdarkness, creaking wood and roaring water,â€ so the river is changing as they ascend. I do hope that my darling will not run any chance of dangerâ€”more than need be; but we are in Godâ€™s hands.

es_translation: November 2nd, in the morning. I was successful and we took turns driving throughout the night; now it is already daytime and the weather is clear despite being cold. There is a strange heaviness in the air...; I say heaviness because I can't find a better word; I mean it oppresses us both. It is very cold and only our warm skins allow us to feel comfortable. At dawn, Van Helsing hypnotized me, he says I answered: "Darkness, the rubbing of wood, and roaring water," so the river is changing as they ascend. My great desire is that my beloved is not in any danger; no more than necessary, but we are in God's hands.

tr_translation: 2 November, morning. - I made it and we drove the car in turns all night; morning came, the weather is bright but cold. There is a strange heaviness in the air - I call it heaviness because I can't find a better word; what I mean is, the air is bothering both of us. It's very cold and only our warm furs are keeping us comfortable. At dawn, Van Helsing hypnotized me; he said I responded with â€œDarkness, creaking wood, and roaring water,â€ so it means there are changes in the river as they move upstream. I hope, my dear, that you do not face any danger -more than necessary- but we are in God's hands.

vi_translation: â€¢ November 2, morning I succeeded in persuading him: we took turns holding the reins throughout the night. A new day had begun, it was bright but cold. The weather was strangely oppressive, I say oppressive because I couldn't find a more accurate word, as both of us felt an indescribable suffocation. It must be said that it was very cold; without the fur coats, I don't know how we would have managed. At dawn, Van Helsing hypnotized me once again. According to him, I responded: "Pitch dark, the sound of waves roaring, the creaking of wooden planks." So the river is undergoing some transformation as the wooden coffin is being carried upstream. I hope my husband will not be in danger. But anyway, we are still under God's protective embrace.

en: Now to the historical, for as Madam Mina write not in her stenography, I must, in my cumbrous old fashion, that so each day of us may not go unrecorded.

vi_translation: Mina no longer uses shorthand to write her diary, so I have to write it for her, even though I'm not very skilled at it, to ensure that the passing days do not fade into oblivion.

en: We got to the Borgo Pass just after sunrise yesterday morning. When I saw the signs of the dawn I got ready for the hypnotism. We stopped our carriage, and got down so that there might be no disturbance. I made a couch with furs, and Madam Mina, lying down, yield herself as usual, but more slow and more short time than ever, to the hypnotic sleep. As before, came the answer: â€œdarkness and the swirling of water.â€ Then she woke, bright and radiant and we go on our way and soon reach the Pass. At this time and place, she become all on fire with zeal; some new guiding power be in her manifested, for she point to a road and say:â€”
es: Llegamos al Paso del Borgo un poco antes del amanecer, ayer por la maÃ±ana; cuando observÃ© los signos precursores del alba, me preparÃ© a hipnotizarla. Detuvimos la calesa y descendimos, con el fin de que nada nos perturbara. Hice una especie de sofÃ¡ con pieles, y la seÃ±ora Mina, despuÃ©s de acostarse, se prestÃ³ a la hipnosis, como siempre, pero mÃ¡s lenta y brevemente que nunca. Como antes, su respuesta fue: "Oscuridad y aguas agitadas." Luego despertÃ³, vivaz y radiante, y continuamos nuestro camino, para llegar pronto al Paso. En esta hora y lugar, ella se llenÃ³ de un nuevo entusiasmo; un nuevo poder director se manifestÃ³ en ella, ya que seÃ±alÃ³ un camino y dijo:
es_translation: We arrived at the Borgo Pass a little before dawn, yesterday morning; when I observed the signs heralding the dawn, I prepared to hypnotize her. We stopped the carriage and got out, so that nothing would disturb us. I made a sort of couch with furs, and Mrs. Mina, after lying down, submitted to the hypnosis, as always, but more slowly and briefly than ever. As before, her response was: "Darkness and troubled waters." Then she awoke, lively and radiant, and we continued our journey, to soon reach the Pass. At this hour and place, she was filled with a new enthusiasm; a new guiding power manifested in her, as she pointed out a path and said:

tr_translation: Yesterday morning, just after sunrise, we arrived at the Borgo Pass. When I saw the signs of dawn, I prepared for hypnosis. We stopped our carriage and got out so we wouldn't be disturbed. I made a bed from furs, and Madam Mina, as usual but slower and for a shorter duration than before, surrendered herself to hypnotic sleep. The response was the same as before: "Darkness and violently flowing waters." Then she woke up lively and cheerful, and we continued on our way, soon reaching the Pass. Right there and then, Madam Mina was seized by a fervent enthusiasm; surely a new guiding force was manifesting itself because she pointed to one of the roads and spoke:

vi_translation: We arrived at Borgo Pass at dawn yesterday. As soon as I saw the first light of dawn, I immediately stopped the car and told Mina to prepare for hypnosis. I made a temporary bed out of fur coats: Mina would lie on it to enter a trance, but indeed this time it was very difficult for me as well. The answer was still the same: "Pitch dark, swirling water." As soon as she said this, she woke up, her face looking visibly happier and more radiant. We continued on our way and soon crossed the pass. Her enthusiasm had turned her into a very eager person. Clearly, a new strength was guiding her, as I saw her suddenly point towards the road ahead and say:

en: Instinctively, with the dawn coming, I turned to Madam Mina, intending to hypnotise her; but she lay in a deep and sudden sleep, from which I could not wake her. I tried to hypnotise through her sleep, but she made no response, none at all; and the day broke. I fear yet to stir. I have made my fire and have seen the horses, they are all dead. To-day I have much to do here, and I keep waiting till the sun is up high; for there may be places where I must go, where that sunlight, though snow and mist obscure it, will be to me a safety.
es: Instintivamente, al llegar la aurora, me volvÃ­ hacia la seÃ±ora Mina, para tratar de hipnotizarla, pero vi que se habÃ­a quedado repentina y profundamente dormida, y no pude despertarla. TratÃ© de hipnotizarla dormida, pero no me dio ninguna respuesta en absoluto, y el sol saliÃ³. Tengo todavÃ­a miedo de moverme. He hecho fuego y he ido a ver a los caballos. Todos estÃ¡n muertos. Hoy tengo mucho quehacer aquÃ­ y espero hasta que el sol se encuentre ya muy alto, porque puede haber lugares a donde tengo que ir, en los que ese sol, aunque oscurecido por la nieve y la niebla, serÃ¡ para mÃ­ una seguridad.
es_translation: Instinctively, at the arrival of dawn, I turned towards Mrs. Mina to try to hypnotize her, but I saw that she had suddenly and deeply fallen asleep, and I could not wake her. I tried to hypnotize her while she slept, but she gave me no response at all, and the sun rose. I am still afraid to move. I have made a fire and gone to check on the horses. They are all dead. I have much to do here today and I will wait until the sun is very high, because there may be places I need to go where that sun, though dimmed by snow and mist, will be a safety for me.

tr_translation: With the breaking of dawn, I instinctively turned to Madam Mina to hypnotize her, but she had fallen into a deep and sudden sleep, and I couldn't wake her. I tried to hypnotize her in her sleep, but she didn't respond at all, and morning came. I am still afraid to move. I lit my fire and saw the horses; they were all dead. I have a lot of work to do here today, and I am waiting until the sun rises fully, because although the snow and mist obscure it, I may need to go to some places where daylight will be my assurance.

vi_translation: Like an instinct, I turned to look at Mina, intending to tell her to prepare for another hypnosis attempt. But she had fallen into a deep sleep without me noticing. Knowing that I couldn't wake her up, I tried to risk hypnotizing her even while she was asleep. But she didn't respond to any questions. I quietly went to prepare the carriage to continue our journey, but my God, the sight before me made my legs go weak: our horses had frozen to death at some point. I understood that a new day would bring me many hardships. I would wait until the sun was high in the sky, because only then, even if it snowed or was foggy, I would feel secure going to the places I needed to reach.

en: The leader, with a quick movement of his rein, threw his horse out in front, and pointing first to the sunâ€”now close down on the hill topsâ€”and then to the castle, said something which I did not understand. For answer, all four men of our party threw themselves from their horses and dashed towards the cart. I should have felt terrible fear at seeing Jonathan in such danger, but that the ardour of battle must have been upon me as well as the rest of them; I felt no fear, but only a wild, surging desire to do something. Seeing the quick movement of our parties, the leader of the gypsies gave a command; his men instantly formed round the cart in a sort of undisciplined endeavour, each one shouldering and pushing the other in his eagerness to carry out the order.
es: El lÃ­der, con un rÃ¡pido movimiento de sus riendas, lanzÃ³ su caballo hacia el frente, dirigiÃ©ndose primeramente hacia el sol, que estaba ya muy cerca de las cimas de las montaÃ±as y, luego, hacia el castillo, diciendo algo que no pude comprender. Como respuesta, los cuatro hombres de nuestro grupo desmontaron de sus caballos y se lanzaron rÃ¡pidamente hacia la carreta. DebÃ­a haberme sentido terriblemente aterrorizada al ver a Jonathan en un peligro tan grande, pero el ardor de la batalla se habÃ­a apoderado de mÃ­, lo mismo que de todos los demÃ¡s; no tenÃ­a miedo, sino un deseo salvaje y apremiante de hacer algo. Viendo el rÃ¡pido movimiento de nuestros amigos, el lÃ­der de los gitanos dio una orden y sus hombres se formaron instantÃ¡neamente en torno a la carreta, en una formaciÃ³n un tanto indisciplinada, empujÃ¡ndose y estorbÃ¡ndose unos a otros, en su afÃ¡n por ejecutar la orden con rapidez.
es_translation: The leader, with a quick movement of his reins, launched his horse forward, heading first towards the sun, which was already very close to the mountain peaks, and then towards the castle, saying something I could not understand. In response, the four men in our group dismounted from their horses and quickly rushed towards the carriage. I should have felt terribly terrified to see Jonathan in such great danger, but the fervor of the battle had taken hold of me, just like everyone else; I was not afraid, but had a wild and pressing desire to do something. Seeing the quick movement of our friends, the leader of the gypsies gave an order and his men instantly formed around the carriage, in a somewhat disorganized formation, pushing and hindering each other in their eagerness to execute the order quickly.

tr_translation: The leader of the community spurred his horse forward with a swift movement of the reins and, pointing first to the sun, which was now approaching the hills, and then to the castle, uttered some words I did not understand. In response, four men from our team dismounted from their horses and quickly ran towards the carriage. When I saw Jonathan putting himself in such danger, I should have been horrified, but the fire of battle must have affected me like the others; I felt no fear, only a wild and great desire to do something. Seeing the quick movement of our team, the chieftain gave an order; his men instantly formed an undisciplined circle around the carriage, each one pushing and shoving the other to carry out the command.

vi_translation: The leader pulled the reins, urging his horse to break away from the group and move to the front, pointing towards the sun that was setting very close to the mountain peaks and the castle, then said something. In response, each member of our group of four allies immediately dismounted and rushed towards the carriage. Seeing Jonathan rush into the danger zone should have made me tremble with fear, but the thrill of the battle made me and my friends forget everything. I did not show any fear, but only had a wild desire to fight. At our unexpected action, the leader shouted out orders once more. The Bohemian crowd immediately gathered around the carriage, forming a chaotic circle.
